{{Infobox film awards | number = 15 | award = Bangladesh National Film Awards| award_link = National Film Awards (Bangladesh) | image = | alt = | caption = | awarded_for = Best of bangladeshi cinema in 1990 | award_org = [[President of Bangladesh]] | presenting_org = [[Ministry of Information (Bangladesh)|Ministry of Information]] | announced_date = | presented_date = 1990 | site = [[Dhaka]], Bangladesh | host = | website = [http://www.moi.gov.bd/ Official website] | best_feature = ''[[Goriber Bou]]'' | best_non_feature = ''[[Amra Tomader Bhulbo Na]]'' | best_actor = [[Alamgir (actor)|Alamgir]] | best_actor_film = ''Moroner Pore'' | best_actress = [[Shabana (actress)|Shabana]] | best_actress_film = ''Moroner Pore'' | most_wins = ''[[Goriber Bou]]'' (5) | last = 14th | next = 16th }} The '''15th Bangladesh National Film Awards''', presented by Ministry of Information, Bangladesh to felicitate the best of Bangladeshi Cinema released in 1990. The ceremony took place in Dhaka and awards were given by then President of Bangladesh. The National Film Awards are the only film awards given by the government itself. Every year, a national panel appointed by the government selects the winning entry, and the award ceremony is held in [[Dhaka]]. 1990 was the 15th ceremony of [[National Film Awards (Bangladesh)|National Film Awards]].{{cite news|url=http://glitz.bdnews24.com/details.php?catry=2&showns=2012 |title=চার দশকে আমাদের সেরা চলচ্চিত্রগুলো |date= |work=bdnews24 |author=Rashed Shaon |accessdate=November 4, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121228185658/http://glitz.bdnews24.com/details.php?catry=2&showns=2012 |archivedate=December 28, 2012 |df= }} ==List of winners== This year awards were given in 18 categories. ===Merit Awards=== {| class="wikitable" |- ! style="background:#EEDD82;"|Name of Awards ! style="background:#EEDD82;"|Winner(s) ! style="background:#EEDD82;"|Film |- |Best Film || S. S. Productions (Producer) ||''[[Goriber Bou]]'' |- |Best Short Film || || ''[[Amra Tomader Bhulbo Na]]'' |- |Best Director || Kamal Ahmed ||''Goriber Bou'' |- |Best Actor || [[Alamgir (actor)|Alamgir]] ||''Moroner Pore'' |- |Best Actress || [[Shabana (actress)|Shabana]] ||''Moroner Pore'' |- |Best Actor in a Supporting Role || [[Golam Mustafa]] ||''[[Chhutir Phande]]'' |- |Best Actress in a Supporting Role || [[Anwara Begum|Anwara]] ||''Moroner Pore'' |- |Best Child Artist || Baby Joya ||''[[Dolna (film)|Dolna]]'' |- |Best Music Director || [[Alauddin Ali]] ||''[[Lakhe Ekta]]'' |- |Best Lyrics || [[Moniruzzaman Monir]]
Shahidul Haque Khan ||''Dolna''{{cite news|url=http://www.sylhetexpress.com/news/details.php?id=6214|title=পরিবারের সবাই চেয়েছিলেন ডাক্তার হবেন তিনি হলেন গীতিকার মনিরুজ্জামান মনির|author=Selim Aowal|newspaper=Sylhet Express|date=2011-10-04|accessdate=October 31, 2015}}
''Chhutir Phande''{{cite news|url=http://www.amardeshonline.com/pages/weekly_news/2010/11/23/9365 |title=শেকড় সন্ধানী একজন |author=R Hossain |date=November 23, 2010 |accessdate=November 5, 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304061159/http://www.amardeshonline.com/pages/weekly_news/2010/11/23/9365 |archivedate=March 4, 2016 |df= }} |- |Best Male Playback Singer|| [[Syed Abdul Hadi]] ||''Goriber Bou''{{cite news|url=http://www.observerbd.com/2014/11/21/55961.php|title=Syed Abdul Hadi performs today at IGCC|newspaper=The Daily Observer|date=2014-11-21|accessdate=September 30, 2015}} |- |Best Female Playback Singer || [[Shahnaz Rahmatullah]] ||''Chhutir Phande''{{cite news|url=http://news.priyo.com/entertainment/2012/09/08/shahnaz-rahmatullah-59248.html|title=Shahnaz Rahmatullah at ‘Bela Obela Sarabela’|newspaper=Priyo News|date=September 8, 2012|access-date=2015-09-30|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151001194809/http://news.priyo.com/entertainment/2012/09/08/shahnaz-rahmatullah-59248.html|archive-date=2015-10-01|dead-url=yes|df=}} |} ===Technical Awards=== {| class="wikitable" |- ! style="background:#EEDD82;"|Name of Awards ! style="background:#EEDD82;"|Winner(s) ! style="background:#EEDD82;"|Film |- |Best Screenplay || [[Shibli Sadiq]] ||''Dolna'' |- |Best Art Director || Abdus Sabur ||''[[Surjogrohon]]'' |- |Best Editing || Aminul Islam Mintu and Zinnat Hossain Biplob || ''Goriber Bou'' |- |Best Sound Editing || Mafizul Haque ||''Dolna'' |} ===Special Awards=== * Best Child Artist (Special) - Master Dodul for ? ==See also== *[[Bachsas Awards]] *[[Meril Prothom Alo Awards]] *[[Ifad Film Club Award]] *[[Babisas Award]] ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== {{Bangladesh National Film Awards}} {{National Cinema Awards}} {{DEFAULTSORT:National Film Awards (Bangladesh)}} [[Category:Cinema of Bangladesh]] [[Category:Bangladeshi awards]] [[Category:Bangladeshi media awards]] [[Category:Awards established in 1975]] [[Category:Bangladeshi film awards]]

{{no footnotes|date=February 2016}} '''''Anowa''''' is a [[play (theatre)|play]] by [[Ghana]]ian playwright [[Ama Ata Aidoo]] published in 1970. It is based on a traditional [[Ghana|Ghanaian]] tale of a daughter who rejects [[Courtship|suitors]] proposed by her parents, Osam and Badua, and marries a stranger who ultimately is revealed as [[Devil|the Devil]] in disguise. The play is set in the 1870s on [[Gold Coast (region)|the Gold Coast]], and tells the story of the heroine Anowa's failed marriage to the slave trader Kofi Ako.
The play has a unique trait where a couple, an old man and an old woman, play the role of the [[Chorus effect|Chorus]]. They present themselves at crucial points in the play and give their own views on the events in the play.
Anowa's attitude of being a modern independent woman angers Kofi Ako. He requests her to be like other normal women. Anowa lives in a [[Hallucination|hallucinated world]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.dictionary.com/browse/hallucination|title=the definition of hallucination|website=Dictionary.com|access-date=2018-03-22}}</ref> and the sorrow of not bearing a child [[depression (mood)|depresses]] her. Her rich husband, now [[frustrated]] with his wife asks her to leave him. Anowa argues with him and finds out that he had lost his ability to bear children and the fault was in him and not in her. This disclosure of the truth drives Kofi Ako to shoot himself and Anowa drowns herself.
Anowa represents the modern woman who likes to make her own decisions and live life as per her choice. An additional conflict is that although a [[Tribe|tribal]] woman, she has the traits of a city-bred. Her attitude leads to her destruction.
==References== *{{cite book|title=Postcolonial African Writers: A Bio-bibliographical Critical Sourcebook|author1=Parekh, P.N.|author2=Jagne, S.F.|date=1998|publisher=Greenwood Press|isbn=9780313290565|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=lvI-Xw5CJdwC&pg=PA32|page=32|accessdate=2015-11-09}} *{{cite book|title=Postcolonial Plays: An Anthology|author=Gilbert, H.|date=2001|publisher=Routledge|isbn=9780415164498|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=OtI5soV04bMC&pg=PA97|page=97|accessdate=2015-11-09}}
[[Category:Ghanaian literature]] [[Category:Theatre in Ghana]] [[Category:Ghanaian plays]]

{{refimprove|date=December 2014}} {{complete rewrite|date=December 2014}} '''Antakshri''' also known as '''Anthyakshari''' is a [[spoken game|spoken]] [[parlour game|parlor game]] played in [[India]].{{Citation | title=Sikh women in England: their religious and cultural beliefs and social practices | author=S. K. Rait | publisher=Trentham Books, 2005 | isbn=978-1-85856-353-4 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=hRfkTq1ykSIC | quote=''... playing antakshri (a group singing game) ...''}} Each contestant sings the first verse of a song (often [[Hindustani classical music|Classical Hindustani]] or [[Bollywood songs|Bollywood song]]s) that begins with the [[Hindustani language|Hindustani]] [[consonant]] on which the previous contestant's song selection ended. ==Etymology== The word is derived from two [[Sanskrit]] words: # Sanskrit ''Antya'' (अन्त्य) meaning End (adjective) # Sanskrit ''Akshar'' (अक्षर) meaning letter of the [[alphabet]] When these words are combined and an '-i' suffixed, the term means "''The game of the ending letter''". It is known as ''Anthyakshari'' the same as Sanskrit only in [[Telugu language|Telugu]] and no other Indian language. Due to [[Schwa deletion in Indo-Aryan languages|schwa syncope in Hindi]] and other Indo-Aryan languages, Anthakshari is pronounced *''antaksh.ri''in Hindi, *"antak.di" in Gujarati, *"antakkhori" in Bangla (and not ''Antakshari'', though that spelling is common in transliteration).{{Citation | title=Allied Chambers transliterated Hindi-Hindi-English dictionary |author1=Henk W. Wagenaar |author2=S. S. Parikh |author3=D. F. Plukker |author4=R. Veldhuijzen van Zanten | publisher=Allied Publishers, 1993 | isbn=978-81-86062-10-4 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=H1LzD8-iipgC | quote=''... अन्ताक्षरी : antākshri ...''}} A dialectical variation of the word is इन्ताक्षरी or ''Intakshri''.{{Citation needed|date=March 2011}} ==Origin== Anthakshari was originally present in the Ramayana, where rishis (sages) sang the first verses of bhajanas continuously by singing another Bhajana beginning with the last letter of the ending word. ==Rules== The game can be played by two or more people and is popular as a group activity during commutes, bus rides etc. The first singer has to sing two complete lines and then s/he may stop at the end of those or following lines. The last Hindi letter of the last word sung is then used by the next singer to sing another song, starting with that letter. The winner or winning team is decided by a process of elimination. The person or team that cannot come up with a song with the right consonant is eliminated if their opponents can produce such a song. The game is often kicked off with the consonant /m/ (म or م) with the recitation of the following couplet which varies, but usually has wording similar to -
Baithe, baithe, kya karein? Karna hai kuch kaam,
Shuru karo antakshri, leke prabhu/rabb ka naa'''m'''!
* This means that the first song must start with (m). * Songs have to be started from the last sound of the previous song. * Only songs from [[Hindustani classical music]] or [[Bollywood]] movies are allowed by default. Songs from other languages can be allowed with prior agreement. * At least the first verse of the song must be sung. If the singer does not remember it in entirety, they cannot use the song. * No song can be repeated in the game. ==Popularity== It started as a [[family]] [[pastime]]. Now there are several TV shows and competitions all over India based on it. The classic style is where two or more teams sing songs which start with last consonant letter of the song sung by previous team. When a team sings a song they earn points. A popular Indian television program by the same name has run successfully on [[Zee TV]] for over 10 years. [[Annu Kapoor]] was the permanent male host while female hosts included Durga Jasraj, Renuka Shahane, Pallavi Joshi, Shefali, Rajeshwari Sachdev & Richa Sharma . Contestants have ranged from school and college-goers to housewives, professionals and celebrities. Mr.Gajendra Singh is known as the Creator of Musical Reality shows in India, Talent Scout extraordinaire’ and a true Visionary who revolutionized the Indian Cable TV scene. He is the man behind conceptualizing 'Antakshari' as a TV show and creating history. The team names of the Zee TV show are Deewane, Parwane, and Mastane. ==Example== आ चल के तुझे, मैं ले के चलूं, इक ऐसे गगन के तले
जहां ग़म भी न हो, आँसू भी न हो, बस प्यार ही प्यार प'''ले'''
''(Movie: [[Door Gagan Ki]])'' This song ends with ले (le), i.e. the consonant /l/ ल. The next contestant could sing - '''ल'''ग जा गले कि फिर ये हसीन रात हो न हो
शायद फिर इस जनम में मुलाक़ात हो न हो
''(Movie: [[Woh Kaun Thi]])'' ===Example=== Kehne ko jashn-e-bahaaraa hai,
Ishq yeh dekh ke hairaan hai,
Phool se khushboo khafa khafa hain gulshan mein,
Chupa hai koi ranj fiza ki chilman mein.
''(Movie: [[Jodhaa Akbar]])'' The next song should begin with /m/ (the 'n' in ''mein'' is only a nasalization rather than a complete consonant, similar to ''bon''/''good'' in French): Mai zindagi ka saath nibhata chala gaya, Har fiqr ko dhuen mein uraata chala gaya,
Barbadiyon ka sog manana fizool tha, Barbadiyon ka jashn manata chala gaya.
''(Movie: [[Hum Dono (1961 film)]])'' The next song should begin with (y) and so on. ==Related games== [[Bait Bazi]] is a related game played with Urdu poetry instead of movie songs. Several [[word chain]] games also resemble ''antakshri'' in their basic methodology. ==See also== * [[Antakshari – The Great Challenge]] * [[Antakshari Intercollegiate Championship]] * [[Bait Bazi]] * [[Baas-o-Beyt]] * [[Bollywood songs]] * [[Titan Antakshari|Zee Tv's Antakshari]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== [[Category:Multiplayer games]] [[Category:Indian games]]

revision.comment: Reverted [[WP:AGF|good faith]] edits by [[Special:Contributions/Pageofswords|Pageofswords]]: Thanks for starting a talk page discussion - we should keep the original wording until there is a consensus to change it. ([[WP:TW|TW]])
revision.text:
{{About|the systematic defense of a religious position|the Christian parody band|ApologetiX}} {{Redirect|Apologist|non-religious uses of ''apologetic'' and ''apologist''|Apology (disambiguation)}} {{more footnotes|date=July 2016}} {{pov|date=March 2018}}
'''Apologetics''' (from [[Greek language|Greek]] {{lang|grc|ἀπολογία}}, "speaking in defense") is the religious discipline of defending [[religious doctrine]]s through systematic [[argument]]ation and discourse.<ref name=":0">{{cite web |url=http://www.blueletterbible.org/lang/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?Strongs=G627 |title=ἀπολογία |work=Blue Letter Bible-Lexicon |accessdate=19 September 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.newadvent.org/cathen/01618a.htm |title=Apologetics |date= |website=The Advent |publisher= |accessdate=24 September 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/apologetics |title=apologetics |date= |website=[[Merriam-Webster Dictionary]] |publisher= |accessdate=5 October 2016}}</ref> [[List of early Christian writers|Early Christian writers]] (c. 120–220) who defended their beliefs against [[criticism of Christianity|critics]] and recommended their [[faith]] to outsiders were called [[Christian apologists]].<ref>{{cite book |chapter=Apologists |editor1-last=Cross |editor1-first=F. L. |editor1-link=Frank Leslie Cross |work=The Oxford Dictionary of the Christian Church |location=New York |publisher=[[Oxford University Press]] |year=2005}}</ref> In 21st-century usage, ''apologetics'' is often identified with debates over [[religion]] and [[theology]].
==Etymology== The term ''apologetics'' derives from the [[Ancient Greek]] word ''apologia''.<ref name=":0" /> In the Classical Greek legal system, two key technical terms were employed: the prosecution delivered the ''kategoria'' (κατηγορία), and the defendant replied with an ''apologia''. To deliver an ''apologia'' meant making a formal speech or giving an explanation to reply and rebut the charges, as in the case of [[Socrates]]' [[Apology (Plato)|Apologia]] defense, as chronicled in [[Apology (Plato)|Plato's ''Apology'']] (the defense speech of [[Socrates]] at his trial). This term appears in the [[Koine Greek]] of the [[New Testament]]. The [[Apostle Paul]] employs the term ''apologia'' in his trial speech to [[Porcius Festus|Festus]] and [[Agrippa I|Agrippa]] when he says "I make my defense" in [[Acts 26]]:2.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.blueletterbible.org/kjv/act/26/2/s_1044002|title=Acts 26:2|last=|first=|date=19 September 2016|website=Blue Letter Bible|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref> A [[cognate]] form appears in Paul's [[Letter to the Philippians]] as he is "defending the gospel" in Philippians 1:7,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.blueletterbible.org/kjv/phl/1/7/s_1104007|title=Phl 1:7|last=|first=|date=19 September 2016|website=Blue Letter Bible|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref> and in "giving an answer" in 1 Peter 3:15.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.blueletterbible.org/kjv/1pe/3/15/s_1154015|title=1Pe 3:15|last=|first=|date=19 September 2016|website=Blue Letter Bible|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref>
Although the term ''apologetics'' has Western, primarily Christian origins and is most frequently associated with the defense of Christianity, the term is sometimes used referring to the defense of any religion in formal debate involving religion.
== Apologetic positions ==
===Bahá'í=== {{main article|Bahá'í apologetics}} Many [[Bahá'í literature#Apologia|apologetic books]] have been written in defence of the history or teachings of the [[Bahá'í Faith]]. The religion's founders wrote several books presenting proofs of their religion, among them are the [[Báb]]'s ''[[Selections from the Writings of the Báb#Dalá'il-i-Sab'ih (The Seven Proofs)|Seven Proofs]]'' and [[Bahá'u'lláh]]'s ''[[Kitáb-i-Íqán]]''.<ref name="PSmith">{{cite encyclopedia |last= Smith |first= Peter |encyclopedia= A concise encyclopedia of the Bahá'í Faith |title= apologetics |year= 2000 |publisher=Oneworld Publications |location= Oxford |pages= 39–40 |isbn= 1-85168-184-1}}</ref> Later Bahá'í authors wrote prominent apologetic texts, such as [[Mírzá Abu'l-Fadl]]'s ''The Brilliant Proof'' and [[Udo Schaefer]] et al.'s ''Making the Crooked Straight'';.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://bahai-library.com/cannuyer_schaefer_desinformation|title=Making the Crooked Straight, by Udo Schaefer, Nicola Towfigh, and Ulrich Gollmer|work=bahai-library.com}}</ref>
===Buddhism=== One of the earliest Buddhist apologetic texts is ''[[Milinda Panha|The Questions of King Milinda]]'', which deals with the Buddhist metaphysics such as the "no-self" nature of the individual and characteristics such as of wisdom, perception, volition, feeling, consciousness and the soul. In the mid-19th century, encounters between Buddhists and Christians in [[Religion in Japan|Japan]] prompted the formation of a Buddhist Propagation Society {{Citation needed|date=September 2016}}. In recent times, A. L. De Silva, an Australian convert to [[Buddhism]], has written a book, ''Beyond Belief'', providing Buddhist apologetic responses and a critique of Christian Fundamentalist doctrine.<ref>{{Cite book|url=http://www.buddhanet.net/pdf_file/beyond-belief02.pdf|title=Beyond Belief, a Buddhist Critique of Fundamentalist Christianity|last=De Silva|first=A. L.|publisher=Three Gems Publications, ebook link at Buddha Dharma Education Association Incorporated, also|year=1994|isbn=978-0-6462-1211-1|location=|pages=|via=}}</ref> Gunapala Dharmasiri wrote an apologetic critique of the [[God in Christianity|Christian concept of God]] from a [[Theravada|Theravadan Buddhist]] perspective.<ref>{{Cite book|title=A Buddhist critique of the Christian concept of God : a critique of the concept of God in contemporary Christian theology and philosophy of religion from the point of view of early Buddhism|last=Dharmasiri|first=Gunapala|publisher=Colombo : Lake House Investments|year=1974|isbn=|location=|pages=|via=WorldCat}}</ref>
===Christianity=== {{Main article|Christian apologetics}} [[File:Shield-Trinity-Scutum-Fidei-compact.svg|thumb|260px|The [[Scutum Fidei]], a diagram frequently used by [[Christian]] apologists to explain the [[Trinity]]]]
Christian apologetics combines [[Christian theology]], [[natural theology]],<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.iep.utm.edu/theo-nat/ | title=Natural Theology | publisher=Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy | accessdate=10 March 2015 | author=Brent, James}}</ref> and [[philosophy]] to present a rational basis for the Christian faith, to defend the faith against objections and misrepresentation.
Christian apologetics has taken many forms over the centuries. In the [[Roman Empire]], Christians were severely persecuted, and many charges were brought against them. J. David Cassel<ref>J. David Cassel. "Defending the Cannibals: How Christians responded to the sometimes strange accusations of their critics." {{cite web|url=http://www.ctlibrary.com/ch/1998/issue57/57h012.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-09-08 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110821133320/http://www.ctlibrary.com/ch/1998/issue57/57h012.html |archivedate=2011-08-21 |df= }}</ref> gives several examples: [[Tacitus]] wrote that [[Nero]] fabricated charges that Christians started the [[Great Fire of Rome|burning of Rome]].<ref>Tacitus, Annals XV.44</ref> Other charges included [[cannibalism]] (due to a literal interpretation of the [[Eucharist]]) and [[incest]] (due to early Christians' practice of addressing each other as "brother" and "sister"). [[Saul of Tarsus]], [[Justin Martyr]], [[Irenaeus]] and others often defended Christianity against charges that were brought to justify persecution.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.christianity.com/church/church-history/timeline/1-300/why-early-christians-were-despised-11629610.html|title=Why Early Christians Were Despised|last=|first=|date=|website=Christianity Today (Church history timeline).|publisher=|access-date=21 September 2016}}</ref>
Later apologists have focused on providing reasons to accept various aspects of Christian belief. Christian apologists of many traditions, in common with Jews, Muslims, and some others, argue for the existence of a unique and personal God. [[Theodicy]] is one important aspect of such arguments, and [[Alvin Plantinga]]'s arguments have been highly influential in this area. Many prominent Christian apologists are scholarly philosophers or theologians, frequently with additional doctoral work in [[physics]], [[cosmology]], [[comparative religions]], or other fields. Others take a more popular or pastoral approach. Some prominent modern apologists are [[Douglas Groothuis]], [[Frederick Copleston]], [[John Lennox]], [[Walter Ralston Martin|Walter R. Martin]], [[Dinesh D'Souza]], [[Douglas Wilson (theologian)|Douglas Wilson]], [[Cornelius Van Til]], [[Gordon Clark]], [[Francis Schaeffer]], [[Greg Bahnsen]], [[Edward John Carnell]], [[James White (theologian)|James White]], [[R.C. Sproul]], [[Hank Hanegraaff]], [[Ravi Zacharias]], [[Alister McGrath]], [[Lee Strobel]], [[Josh McDowell]], [[Peter Kreeft]], [[G. K. Chesterton]], [[C. S. Lewis]], [[William Lane Craig]], [[J. P. Moreland]], [[Hugh Ross (creationist)|Hugh Ross]], [[David Bentley Hart]], [[Gary Habermas]], [[Norman Geisler]] and [[Scott Hahn]].<ref>[http://www.catholiceducation.org/articles/apologetics/ap0088.html/ Catholic Education Resource Center: ''The Scott Hahn Conversion Story''] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120718093548/http://www.catholiceducation.org/articles/apologetics/ap0088.html/ |date=July 18, 2012 }}</ref>
Notable apologists within the [[Catholic Church]] include [[Robert Barron (bishop)|Bishop Robert Barron]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wordonfire.org/about/fr-robert-barron/|title=Page Not Found - Word On Fire|publisher=}}</ref> [[G. K. Chesterton]],<ref>{{cite book|title=The Everlasting Man|last=Chesterton|first=G K|publisher=Wilder Publications|year=2008|isbn=160459246X|location=Radford|page=180}}</ref> [[Scott Hahn|Dr. Scott Hahn]], [[Patrick Madrid]], Kenneth Hensley,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://catholicapologeticsacademy.com/faculty/kenneth-hensley/|title=Kenneth Hensley - Catholic Apologetics Academy|publisher=}}</ref> [[Karl Keating]], [[Ronald Knox]], [[Peter Kreeft]], and Gus Loyd.
[[John Henry Newman]] (February 21, 1801 – August 11, 1890) was an English convert to [[Roman Catholic Church|Roman Catholicism]], later made a [[Cardinal (Catholicism)|cardinal]], and [[beatified]] in 2010. In early life he was a major figure in the [[Oxford Movement]] to bring the [[Church of England]] back to its Catholic roots. Eventually his studies in history persuaded him to become a Roman Catholic. When John Henry Newman entitled his spiritual autobiography ''[[Apologia Pro Vita Sua]]'' in 1864, he was playing upon both this connotation, and the more commonly understood meaning of an expression of contrition or regret.
Christian apologists employ a variety of philosophical and formal approaches, including [[Ontological argument|ontological]], [[Cosmological argument|cosmological]], and [[teleological argument]]s.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.bethinking.org/apologetics/an-introduction-to-christian-apologetics?Strongs=G627|title=An Introduction to Christian Apologetics|last=Coulter|first=Paul|date=|website=Bethinking|publisher=|access-date=21 September 2016}}</ref> The Christian presuppositionalist approach to apologetics utilizes the [[transcendental argument for the existence of God]].<ref>Apologetics: A Justification of Christian Belief John Frame-Joseph Torres - P&R Publishing - 2015 p. 67f</ref>
[[Tertullian]] was a notable early [[Christian]] apologist. He was born, lived and died in [[Carthage]]. He is sometimes known as the "Father of the [[Latin Church]]". He introduced the term ''[[Trinity]]'' ([[Latin]] ''trinitas'') to the Christian vocabulary<ref>''A History of Christian Thought'', [[Paul Tillich]], Touchstone Books, 1972. {{ISBN|0-671-21426-8}} (p. 43)</ref> and also probably{{Citation needed|date=January 2009}} the formula "three Persons, one Substance" as the Latin "tres [[Persona]]e, [[Consubstantial|una Substantia]]" (itself from the [[Koine Greek]] "treis [[Hypostasis (religion)|Hypostaseis]], [[Ousios|Homoousios]]"), and also the terms ''Vetus Testamentum'' ([[Old Testament]]) and ''Novum Testamentum'' ([[New Testament]]).
====Mormonism==== {{further information|Mormon studies#Apologetics}} There are notable Latter-day Saint apologists who focus on the defense of [[Mormonism]], including early church leaders such as [[Parley P. Pratt]], [[John Taylor (1808-1887)|John Taylor]], [[B. H. Roberts]], [[James E. Talmage]] and more modern figures such as [[Hugh Nibley]], [[Orson Scott Card]], and [[Jeff Lindsay (engineer)|Jeff Lindsay]].
Several well-known Mormon apologetic organizations, such as the [[Foundation for Ancient Research and Mormon Studies]] (a group of scholars at [[Brigham Young University]]) and [[FairMormon]] (an independent, Mormon-run, not-for-profit group), have been formed to defend the doctrines and history of the [[Latter Day Saint movement]] in general and [[The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints]] in particular.
=== Deism === [[Deism]] is a form of [[theism]] in which God created the universe and established rationally comprehensible moral and natural laws but no longer intervenes in human affairs. Deism is a [[natural religion]] where belief in God is based on application of reason and evidence observed in the designs and laws found in nature.<sup>[[Criticism of atheism#cite note-12|[12]]]</sup> The World Order of Deists maintains a web site presenting deist apologetics that demonstrate the existence of God based on evidence and reason, absent divine revelation.
===Hinduism=== Hindu apologetics began developing during the British colonial period. A number of Indian intellectuals had become critical of the British tendency to devalue the Hindu religious tradition. As a result, these Indian intellectuals, as well as a handful of British [[Indology|Indologists]], were galvanized to examine the roots of the religion as well as to study its vast arcana and corpus in an analytical fashion. This endeavor drove the deciphering and preservation of [[Sanskrit]]. Many translations of Hindu texts were produced which made them accessible to a broader reading audience.
A range of Indian philosophers, including [[Swami Vivekananda]] and [[Aurobindo Ghose]], have written rational explanations regarding the values of the Hindu religious tradition. More modern proponents such as the [[Maharishi Mahesh Yogi]] have also tried to correlate recent developments from [[quantum physics]] and [[consciousness]] research with Hindu concepts. The late Reverend [[Pandurang Shastri Athavale]] has given a plethora of discourses regarding the symbolism and rational basis for many principles in the [[Veda|Vedic tradition]]. In his book ''The Cradle of Civilization'', David Frawley, an American who has embraced the Vedic tradition, has characterized the ancient texts of the Hindu heritage as being like "pyramids of the spirit". [[A. C. Bhaktivedanta Swami Prabhupada]] translated over sixty volumes of classic Vedic scriptures including the biography and conclusions of the famous 16th century bhakti scholar [[Sri Chaitanya Mahaprabhu]]; many of these translations and commentaries have been further translated into as many as eighty languages, producing over half a billion books distributed throughout the world. Such individuals have tried to construct an intellectual defense of [[Hinduism]] during a phase when the [[Fundamentalism|fundamentalistic]] elements of other faiths have sought to denigrate the ancient religion in an effort to gain converts.
===Islam=== ''Ilm al-Kalām'', literally "science of discourse",<ref name="Wolfson">Winter, Tim J. "Introduction." Introduction. The Cambridge Companion to Classical Islamic Theology. Cambridge: Cambridge UP, 2008. 4–5. Print.</ref> usually foreshortened to ''[[kalam]]'' and sometimes called ''Islamic scholastic theology'', is an Islamic undertaking born out of the need to establish and defend the tenets of Islamic faith against doubters and detractors.<ref>Madeleine Pelner Cosman, Linda Gale Jones, Handbook to Life in the Medieval World, p 391. {{ISBN|1438109075}}</ref> A scholar of ''kalam'' is referred to as a ''mutakallim'' (plural ''mutakallimūn'') as distinguished from philosophers, jurists, and scientists.<ref>Clinton Bennett, The Bloomsbury Companion to Islamic Studies, p 119. {{ISBN|1441127887}}.</ref>
===Judaism=== {{See also|Jewish polemics and apologetics in the Middle Ages}} Jewish apologetic literature can be traced back as far as [[Aristobulus of Paneas]], though some discern it in the works of [[Demetrius the chronographer]] (3rd century BCE) traces of the style of "questions" and "solutions" typical of the genre. Aristobulus was a Jewish philosopher of [[Alexandria]] and the author of an apologetic work addressed to [[Ptolemy VI Philometor]]. [[Josephus]]'s [[Contra Apion]] is a wide-ranging defense of [[Judaism]] against many charges laid against Judaism at that time, as too are some of the works of [[Philo of Alexandria]].<ref>John Granger Cook (2000) ''The Interpretation of the New Testament in Greco-Roman paganism'' p.4., Mohr Siebeck Verlag, Tuebingen, Germany</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jewishencyclopedia.com/articles/1651-apologists|title=APOLOGISTS|work=Jewish Encyclopedia|year=1906}}</ref>
In response to modern Christian missionaries, and congregations that "are designed to appear Jewish, but are actually fundamentalist Christian churches, which use traditional Jewish symbols to lure the most vulnerable of our Jewish people into their ranks",<ref name=Schoon2006p125>Simon Schoon, "Noachides and Converts to Judaism", in [[Jan N. Bremmer]], [[Wout van Bekkum|Wout Jac. van Bekkum]], Arie L. Molendijk. ''Cultures of Conversions'', Peeters Publishers, 2006, {{ISBN|978-90-429-1753-8}}, [https://books.google.com/books?id=7-W-wOgKI9cC&pg=PA125 p. 125].</ref> [[Jews for Judaism]] is the largest counter-missionary organization in existence, today. [[Kiruv Organisation]], founded by Rabbi Yosef Mizrachi, and Outreach Judaism, founded by Rabbi [[Tovia Singer]], are other prominent international organizations that respond "directly to the issues raised by missionaries and cults, by exploring Judaism in contradistinction to fundamentalist Christianity."<ref>[http://www.outreachjudaism.org/about_us.html About Us], Outreach Judaism website. Accessed January 9, 2011.</ref><ref>[[J. Gordon Melton]], "The Modern Anti-Cult Movement in Historical Perspective", in Jeffrey Kaplan, Heléne Lööw. ''The Cultic Milieu: Oppositional Subcultures in an Age of Globalization'', [[Rowman Altamira]], 2002, {{ISBN|978-0-7591-0204-0}}, p. 285, note 4.</ref>
===Pantheism=== Some pantheists have formed organizations such as the [[World Pantheist Movement]] and the [[Universal Pantheist Society]] to promote and defend the belief in [[pantheism]].<ref name=Credo>{{cite web|title=The Pantheist Credo|url=http://www.pantheism.net/manifest.htm|publisher=World Pantheist Movement}}</ref>
===Native Americans=== In a famous speech called "Red Jacket on Religion for the White Man and the Red" in 1805, [[Seneca tribe|Seneca]] chief [[Red Jacket]] gave an apologetic for [[Native Americans in the United States|Native American]] religion.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bartleby.com/268/8/3.html#txt1|title=Red Jacket on the Religion of the White Man and the Red by Red Jacket. America: I. (1761-1837). Vol. VIII. Bryan, William Jennings, ed. 1906. The World's Famous Orations|work=bartleby.com}}</ref>
== In literature == Plato's ''Apology'' may be read as both a religious and literary apology; however, more specifically literary examples may be found in the [[preface]]s and [[dedication]]s, which proceed many [[Early modern period|Early Modern]] plays, novels, and poems. Eighteenth century authors such as [[Colley Cibber]], [[Frances Burney]], and [[William Congreve]], to name but a few, prefaced the majority of their poetic work with such apologies. In addition to the desire to defend their work, the apologetic preface often suggests the author's attempt to humble his- or herself before the audience.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/30105/apology|title=Apology|publisher=Encyclopædia Britannica|work=Britannica Academic Edition|accessdate=14 July 2011}}</ref>

{{Use dmy dates|date=September 2016}} {{Infobox video game | title = Beyond: Two Souls | image = Beyond Two Souls final cover.jpg | alt = The game's cover art; a close-up of Jodie's face with her eyes closed is seen in profile. | developer = [[Quantic Dream]] | publisher = [[Sony Computer Entertainment]] | director = [[David Cage]] | producer = Charles Coutier | writer = David Cage | composer = [[Lorne Balfe]] | platforms = {{Unbulleted list|[[PlayStation 3]]|[[PlayStation 4]]}} | released = {{Collapsible list|titlestyle=font-weight:normal;background:transparent;text-align:left;|title=8 October 2013|'''PlayStation 3'''{{Video game release|NA|8 October 2013|PAL|9 October 2013|UK|11 October 2013}}'''PlayStation 4'''{{Video game release|WW|24 November 2015}}}} | genre = [[Interactive movie|Interactive drama]], [[Action-adventure game|action-adventure]]<!-- Please note that per [[WP:VG]] the 'genre' here means gameplay (i.e. role-playing, first-person shooter etc), not narrative. The article body is meant for that--> | modes = [[Single-player video game|Single-player]], [[two-player video game|two-player]] }}
'''''Beyond: Two Souls''''' is an [[Interactive movie|interactive drama]] and [[action-adventure game]] for the [[PlayStation 3]] and [[PlayStation 4]] home video game consoles, developed by [[Quantic Dream]] and published by [[Sony Interactive Entertainment|Sony Computer Entertainment]]. It was released in October 2013. The [[single-player video game|game]] features Jodie Holmes, one of two [[player character]]s. The other is an [[incorporeality|incorporeal]] entity named Aiden: a separate soul linked to Jodie since birth. Jodie, who is portrayed by actress [[Ellen Page]], possesses supernatural powers through her psychic link to Aiden, growing from adolescence to adulthood while learning to control Aiden and the powers they share. [[Willem Dafoe]] co-stars as Nathan Dawkins, a researcher in the Department of Paranormal Activity and Jodie's surrogate-father-figure. The actors in the game worked during the year-long project in Quantic Dream's Paris studio to perform on-set [[voice acting]] and [[motion-capture acting]].
Despite being a video game, ''Beyond: Two Souls'' premiered at the 2013 [[Tribeca Film Festival]], marking only the second time the film festival recognised a video game. [[David Cage]], writer and director of the game, explained that game development studios should provide "[[interactive storytelling]]" that can be played by everyone, including non-gamers. The game received polarised critical reception upon its release. Sales reached over one million copies two months after its worldwide release by the end of 2013. Two years later, a PlayStation 4 version was released, both as a standalone title and then in the ''Quantic Dream Collection'' with the 2010 title ''[[Heavy Rain]]''.
== Gameplay == ''Beyond: Two Souls'' is an [[Interactive movie|interactive drama]] and [[action-adventure game]], requiring the player to move and guide the character into interactions with objects and other [[non-player character]]s in the scene to progress the story. The player primarily controls Jodie through the in-game environments. At almost any time, however, the player (or second player during a [[two-player video game|two-player game]]) can switch to control Aiden instead. Aiden, as an [[incorporeality|incorporeal]] entity, exists permanently in [[noclip mode]] and can move through walls, ceilings, and other obstacles; however, he is limited to moving only within a certain radius around Jodie due to their spiritual tethering.<ref>{{cite web |title='Beyond: Two Souls' a solid tale bogged down by gameplay |last=Bowers |first=Brian |date=10 October 2013 |work=[[Stars and Stripes (newspaper)|Stars and Stripes]] |url=http://www.stripes.com/military-life/beyond-two-souls-a-solid-tale-bogged-down-by-gameplay-1.246432 |accessdate=25 January 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131014040434/http://www.stripes.com/military-life/beyond-two-souls-a-solid-tale-bogged-down-by-gameplay-1.246432 |archivedate=14 October 2013}}</ref>
While playing as Jodie, the [[game mechanics|game]] includes interactive objects marked with a white dot, which can be interacted with by tilting the [[game controller|controller]] stick in its direction. If Jodie must perform a specific action, [[Icon (computing)|icon]]s pop up on the screen to prompt the player to press and/or hold certain controller buttons. Conversation prompts float in the air, defaulting to a certain choice if too much time passes before selection. During action sequences, like chases or hand-to-hand [[fighting game|combat]], the cinematography moves into [[slow motion]] whilst Jodie performs the physical manoeuvre; during this time, the player must determine the direction Jodie is moving and push the controller stick in that direction to complete the action. Other sequences require real-time [[stealth game|stealth]], which has the player sneak Jodie through environments while coordinating certain actions with Aiden. Failing certain action sequences will alter the course of a chapter (and sometimes later chapters) and in some cases lead to the death of a non-playable character.<ref name="David Cage Gameplay">{{cite web |title=Beyond: Two Souls – Gameplay from E3 2013 |last=Cage |first=David |date=11 June 2013 |work=[[PlayStation Blog]] |publisher=[[Sony Interactive Entertainment]] |url=http://blog.us.playstation.com/2013/06/11/beyond-two-souls-gameplay-from-e3-2013/ |accessdate=25 January 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304085421/http://blog.us.playstation.com/2013/06/11/beyond-two-souls-gameplay-from-e3-2013/ |archivedate=4 March 2016}}</ref><ref name="TrustedReviews Gameplay">{{cite web |title=Beyond: Two Souls review – Gameplay |last=Andrews |first=Stuart |date=October 2014 |work=Trusted Reviews |url=https://www.trustedreviews.com/reviews/beyond-two-souls |accessdate=25 January 2015}}</ref>
While playing as Aiden, the game becomes [[monochrome|monochromatic]]. Amongst the shades of greys, interactive objects are highlighted by an [[aura (paranormal)|aura]] shining in one of several colours, with the colour of the aura indicating his potential interaction: orange characters can be possessed, red characters strangled, blue objects (or characters with environmental effects) knocked around, and green characters healed. Jodie frequently calls upon Aiden to provide different abilities, such as form a protective shield around her, allow the dead to speak to the living through her, grant her an ability to see events of the recent past, and enable her to heal a character's wounds.<ref name="David Cage Gameplay"/><ref name="TrustedReviews Gameplay"/>
As the player makes choices throughout the game, the gameplay's plot is revealed. Besides affecting dialogue and story developments, the outcome of entire scenes (and in some cases, the outcome of scenes several chapters later) can be manipulated to a certain extent based on player choices. These choices are typically moral decisions made through Jodie's dialogue options, interventions with various characters, success or failure in her combat scenes, or psychic actions that the player chooses to have Aiden perform.<ref name="GSpot"/> Examples of choice-based outcomes are the chapter titled The Party, where the player is given the choice of unleashing brutal revenge toward a group of bullies or simply running away, and the chapter titled The Embassy, where the player can either engage in psychic information retrieval or can jeopardise the mission by forcing one of the guards to commit suicide. Choices also determine the finale of ''Beyond: Two Souls'', as any number of possible plot endings can be experienced by the player.<ref>{{cite web |title=Player Choice and Branching Narrative in Beyond: Two Souls |last=Boudreaux |first=Brian |date=29 October 2013 |work=Press X To Story |url=http://www.pressxtostory.com/2015/01/player-choice-and-branching-narrative.html |accessdate=25 January 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150115025929/http://www.pressxtostory.com/2015/01/player-choice-and-branching-narrative.html |archivedate=15 January 2015}}</ref>
== Plot == :''While the story is told through [[nonlinear narrative]], this summary is given in chronological order.''
Young Jodie Holmes (Caroline Wolfson) lives with her foster parents in a suburban home. Since birth, Jodie has had a psychic connection with a mysterious entity named Aiden, with whom she can communicate and perform telepathic acts, such as possessing people's minds and manipulating certain objects. After an incident with some neighbourhood kids results in Aiden almost killing one of them, Jodie's foster parents seek help to care for her condition, permanently leaving her under the custody of doctors Nathan Dawkins ([[Willem Dafoe]]) and Cole Freeman ([[Kadeem Hardison]]) of the United States Department of Paranormal Activity.<ref>{{cite video game |title=Beyond: Two Souls |developer=Quantic Dream |publisher=[[Sony Computer Entertainment]] |date=8 October 2013 |platform=PlayStation 3 |level=My Imaginary Friend, First Interview, First Night, Alone}}</ref>
Under the two doctors' care, Jodie slowly learns to control Aiden and the powers they share. During this time, Nathan and Cole are building the condenser, a portal that connects the world of the living with the world of the dead—the Infraworld. One night, Nathan learns that his wife and daughter were killed in a car accident. While trying to comfort him, Jodie discovers that she can channel spirits of the dead from the Infraworld; she helps the spirits speak to the living through a psychic link created by her physical contact. As the years pass, a teenage Jodie ([[Ellen Page]]) seeks her independence, both from the doctors and from Aiden, and tries several times to live a normal life. At each attempt, Aiden intervenes, ending in disaster.<ref>{{cite video game |title=Beyond: Two Souls |developer=Quantic Dream |publisher=[[Sony Computer Entertainment]] |date=8 October 2013 |platform=PlayStation 3 |level=The Experiment, Night Session, Hauntings, The Party, Like Other Girls}}</ref>
At one point, Nathan asks for Jodie's help with the condenser, which has broken open. After braving hostile entities from the Infraworld, Jodie manages to shut down the condenser and warns Nathan not to build another. This gets the attention of the [[Central Intelligence Agency|CIA]], who send agent Ryan Clayton ([[Eric Winter]]) to forcibly recruit Jodie. After training, the now-adult Jodie goes on multiple missions as a field agent, often with Ryan, to whom she slowly becomes attracted. On one such mission in Somalia, Jodie learns that the target she killed was not a warlord, but the country's benign president. An enraged Jodie flees in disgust, despite Ryan's pleas. Branded a traitor, Jodie becomes a fugitive, evading pursuing CIA forces. Along the way, she befriends a small group of homeless people, one of whom she helps give birth to a girl named Zoey, and she lives with a family of Native Americans, during which she encounters another love interest named Jay and saves them from a malevolent entity. The CIA eventually recaptures Jodie after she attempts to reconnect with her catatonic biological mother, who has been held and forcibly drugged for decades in a military hospital.<ref>{{cite video game |title=Beyond: Two Souls |developer=Quantic Dream |publisher=[[Sony Computer Entertainment]] |date=8 October 2013 |platform=PlayStation 3 |level=The Condenser, Separation, Welcome to the CIA, The Embassy, The Dinner, The Mission, Hunted, Homeless, Broken, Navajo, Old Friends, Nora}}</ref>
The CIA hands Jodie over to Nathan, now executive director of the DPA, overseeing the DPA's newest condenser, code-named the Black Sun. He reveals that the CIA is willing to let Jodie go if she agrees to a final mission. Jodie and a CIA team led by Ryan destroy an underwater facility housing a Chinese-developed condenser before it is used to attack the United States. Jodie then learns that Nathan built a miniature condenser to speak exclusively to his family, but without success. After showing Nathan that his refusal to let them go is only making them suffer, Jodie tries to leave, only to be held in captivity by the CIA—the organisation has deemed her too dangerous to be freed. Jodie is subjected to the same fate as her mother. Nathan appears and informs Jodie that he's decided to shut down the containment field to the Black Sun, merging the two worlds together and making death meaningless. Too weak to free Jodie, Aiden contacts Ryan and Cole, leading them to her. After Nathan shuts down the containment field, the three chase after him into the heart of the Black Sun, with the intent of destroying it.<ref>{{cite video game |title=Beyond: Two Souls |developer=Quantic Dream |publisher=[[Sony Computer Entertainment]] |date=8 October 2013 |platform=PlayStation 3 |level=Briefing, Dragon's Hideout, Black Sun}}</ref>
During the trek towards the Black Sun, Cole is injured by entities and Ryan sacrifices his own safety to keep Jodie alive. Eventually, Jodie confronts Nathan near the Black Sun. He commits suicide to reunite with his family. As Jodie shuts down the condenser, she has a vision—Aiden is her stillborn twin brother. Jodie must make a choice: go back to the world of the living, or go on to the Infraworld and be reunited with everyone she has lost. If Jodie chooses Life, her connection to Aiden is severed and she is no longer useful to the CIA. Jodie must choose how to live her life, either alone or with Ryan, Jay, or Zoey and her family. If Jodie chooses Beyond, she joins Aiden and other lost ones in the Infraworld, dying in the process. She continues to watch over those who remain in the living world, warning the now-teenage Zoey of the coming danger. By the story's end, the Infraworld has become a widespread threat in the not-so-distant future. Jodie prepares to confront the threat.<ref>{{cite video game |title=Beyond: Two Souls |developer=Quantic Dream |publisher=[[Sony Computer Entertainment]] |date=8 October 2013 |platform=PlayStation 3 |level=Black Sun, Epilogue}}</ref>
== Development == [[File:Beyond Two Souls (three scenes).png|thumb|left|Scenes from the game: Jodie Holmes (top), Aiden's view of Nathan Dawkins and young Jodie (note his spiritual tether, middle), Willem Dafoe, David Cage, and Ellen Page working on the motion capture (bottom)]]
[[David Cage]], founder and CEO of [[Quantic Dream]], announced ''Beyond: Two Souls'' at [[Sony Interactive Entertainment|Sony]]'s press conference during the [[Electronic Entertainment Expo 2012]]. He showed the crowd a debut [[trailer (promotion)|trailer]] featuring the game's in-game graphics.<ref name="E3 2012">{{cite web |url=http://www.destructoid.com/e3-quantic-dream-unveils-beyond-two-souls-228754.phtml |title=E3: Quantic Dream unveils Beyond: Two Souls |work=[[Destructoid]] |last=Pinsof |first=Allistair |date=4 June 2012 |accessdate=25 June 2013}}</ref> When he was asked to compare ''Beyond: Two Souls'' to Quantic Dream's previous game ''[[Heavy Rain]]'', Cage described ''Beyond'' as a "more action-driven experience" that offers "much more direct control" and "much more spectacular action" than the 2010 thriller.<ref name="E3 2012"/> Cage has called his games "fully controllable" while admitting "when there is an action sequence, yes we integrate these [[quick time event]] sequences ... in a new way."<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.eurogamer.net/articles/david-cage-rants-about-quick-time-events |title=David Cage rants about quick-time events |work=[[Eurogamer]] |publisher=Gamer Network |date=20 August 2009 |accessdate=25 August 2018}}</ref> Unlike Quantic Dream's previous game, ''Beyond'' was not to be [[PlayStation Move]] compatible.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2013-03-21-heavy-rain-dev-confirms-work-on-ps4-game-has-begun |title=Heavy Rain dev confirms work on PS4 game has begun |work=[[Eurogamer]] |publisher=Gamer Network |date=21 March 2013 |accessdate=21 March 2013}}</ref> Earlier games created by Cage, which have been called "wrought psychological thrillers", demonstrate that emotional narrative is a critical element in a Quantic Dream game's development.<ref name="The Guardian">{{cite web |last=Stuart |first=Keith |url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/gamesblog/2013/mar/22/beyond-two-souls-preview-playstation |title=Beyond: Two Souls review |work=[[The Guardian]] |date=22 March 2013 |accessdate=4 November 2013}}</ref> In an interview, actress Ellen Page noted that the script for the game was around 2,000 pages long<ref name="Page interview">{{cite web |url=http://herocomplex.latimes.com/games/ellen-page-beyond-game/ |title=Ellen Page is 'Beyond' real in 'emotional and subversive' game |last=Pham |first=Alex |work=[[Los Angeles Times]] |date=19 July 2012 |accessdate=29 August 2012}}</ref> (an average screenplay is between 95 and 125 pages long; each page is approximately one minute of screen time).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.screenwriting.info/03.php |title=Screenwriting: Script Length |publisher=Screenwriting.info |date=22 June 2014 |accessdate=22 June 2014}}</ref> "We'd do 30, 40 pages a day. It's insane compared to a film. Jodie goes through a lot. This is an incredibly emotional story and journey for this girl."<ref name="Page interview"/>
Quantic Dream, an advanced [[motion capture]] studio as well as [[video game developer]], required the ''Beyond: Two Souls'' actors to perform [[motion-capture acting]] as well as on-set [[voice acting]].<ref name="The Guardian"/> Ellen Page, Willem Dafoe, Kadeem Hardison, Eric Winter, Caroline Wolfson, and other actors cast in the game worked during the year-long project in the Paris studio to perform the physical actions seen onscreen as performed by their fully realised [[video game graphics|video game graphic]] characters.<ref name="blog.us.playstation.com">{{cite web |url=http://blog.us.playstation.com/2013/09/05/beyond-two-souls-demo-coming-october-1st/ |title=Beyond: Two Souls Demo Coming October 1st |work=[[PlayStation Blog]] |publisher=[[Sony Interactive Entertainment]] |accessdate=25 September 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161224213701/http://blog.us.playstation.com/2013/09/05/beyond-two-souls-demo-coming-october-1st// |archivedate=24 December 2016}}</ref><ref name="ew.com">{{cite web |last=Morales |first=Aaron |date=8 October 2013 |url=http://www.ew.com/article/2013/10/08/ellen-page-beyond-two-souls-review/ |title=Ellen Page elevates 'Beyond: Two Souls' |work=[[Entertainment Weekly]] |accessdate=12 September 2014}}</ref> Meanwhile, Quantic Dream [[video game programmer|programmers]], [[video game artist|artists]], and [[animator]]s, led by art director Christophe Brusseaux, designed the [[computer-generated imagery]] seen in the game. David Cage provided [[video game writer|writing]] and direction and [[Guillaume de Fondaumière]] was the [[video game producer#Types of producers|executive producer]].<ref>{{cite web |last=Ohannessian |first=Kevin |url=https://www.fastcompany.com/1683212/director-david-cage-on-playing-a-life-in-full-in-beyond-two-souls |title=Director David Cage on Playing a Life in Full in "Beyond: Two Souls" |work=Fast Co Create |date=19 July 2013 |accessdate=28 January 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last=Colm |first=Ahern |url=http://www.godisageek.com/2013/10/interview-beyond-souls-executive-producer-guillaume-de-fondaumiere/ |title=Interview: Beyond: Two Souls Executive Producer Guillaume de Fondaumière |work=God Is a Geek |date=11 October 2013 |accessdate=28 January 2015}}</ref>
''Beyond: Two Souls'' is dedicated to composer [[Normand Corbeil]], who died of pancreatic cancer on 25 January 2013.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.engadget.com/2013/01/28/heavy-rain-composer-normand-corbeil-passes-away-aged-56/ |title=Heavy Rain Composer Normand Corbeil Passes Away, Age 56 |work=[[Joystiq]] |date=28 January 2013 |accessdate=16 April 2013}}</ref> Corbeil had worked on Quantic Dream's ''Heavy Rain'' and its predecessor ''[[Fahrenheit (2005 video game)|Fahrenheit]]'' and was unable to finish his work on ''Beyond''. [[Lorne Balfe]], who wrote the [[film score|score]] for ''[[Assassin's Creed III]]'', replaced Corbeil as the game's composer after Corbeil's death.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hans-zimmer.com/index.php?rub=news_3&id_news=862 |title=Lorne Balfe to score the video game BEYOND – TWO SOULS |publisher=Hans-Zimmer.com |date=14 April 2013 |accessdate=25 June 2013}}</ref> Balfe's collaborator [[Hans Zimmer]] joined him as producer in August 2013.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.engadget.com/2013/08/22/beyond-two-souls-soundtrack-from-hans-zimmer-and-lorne-balfe/ |title=Beyond: Two Souls soundtrack from Hans Zimmer and Lorne Balfe |last=Conditt |first=Jessica |work=[[Joystiq]] |date=22 August 2013 |accessdate=23 August 2013}}</ref>
On 27 April 2013, five months before the game's debut, Quantic Dream released a new trailer and demonstrated 35 minutes of the game at the 2013 [[Tribeca Film Festival]], with both Page and Cage in attendance.<ref name="IGN1">{{cite web |last=Thomsen |first=Michael |date=3 May 2013 |url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2013/05/03/beyond-two-souls-woos-movie-goers-at-tribeca-film-festival |title='Beyond: Two Souls' Woos Movie-Goers at Tribeca Film Festival |work=[[IGN]] |publisher=[[Ziff Davis]] |accessdate=12 September 2014}}</ref> This marks only the second time the film festival recognised a video game, the first being 2011's ''[[L.A. Noire]]''.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.destructoid.com/beyond-two-souls-tribeca-trailer-35-minutes-of-footage-252645.phtml |title=Beyond: Two Souls Tribeca trailer + 35 minutes of footage |work=[[Destructoid]] |last=Pinsof |first=Allistair |date=28 April 2013 |accessdate=25 June 2013}}</ref> In interviews conducted immediately prior to the game's worldwide release, Cage explained that development studios like Quantic Dream have an obligation to provide "[[interactive storytelling]]" that can be played by everyone, including non-gamers.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.vg247.com/2013/09/25/beyond-two-souls-david-cage-talks-movies-audience-accessibility/ |title=Beyond: Two Souls – David Cage talks movies, audience, accessibility |publisher=[[VG247]] |last=Hillier |first=Brenna |date=25 September 2013 |accessdate=28 January 2015}}</ref>
== Release == On 5 September 2013, the [[PlayStation Blog]] announced that a [[game demo|demo]] for ''Beyond: Two Souls'' would be released 1 October 2013 in the United States, 2 October for Europe, and 3 October for Japan, about a week prior to the full game's worldwide release. Despite the demo's official release date, a few users of the paid subscription service [[PlayStation Plus]] were allowed to receive the demo a week earlier, on 24 September 2013. [[GameStop]] also gave out a limited number of [[Software release life cycle#Beta|beta]] keys on that day.<ref name="blog.us.playstation.com"/><ref>{{cite web |last=Makuch |first=Eddie |url=http://www.gamespot.com/articles/gamestop-now-offering-beyond-two-souls-beta-keys/1100-6414918/ |title=GameStop now offering Beyond: Two Souls beta keys |work=[[GameSpot]] |publisher=[[CBS Interactive]] |date=24 September 2013 |accessdate=25 September 2013}}</ref> The full game was released on 8 October 2013 in North America, 9 October 2013 in Europe, Australia and New Zealand, and 11 October 2013 in the UK.<ref name=blog>{{cite web |title=Willem Dafoe, Ellen Page Star in Beyond: Two Souls October 8 |work=[[PlayStation Blog]] |publisher=[[Sony Interactive Entertainment]] |last=Osgood |first=Derek |date=1 March 2013 |url=http://blog.us.playstation.com/2013/03/01/willem-dafoe-ellen-page-star-in-beyond-two-souls-october-8th/ |accessdate=25 June 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130523070057/http://blog.us.playstation.com/2013/03/01/willem-dafoe-ellen-page-star-in-beyond-two-souls-october-8th/ |archivedate=23 May 2013}}</ref><ref name=AUSreleasedate>{{cite web |url=https://progressbar.com.au/news/beyond-two-souls-release-date-announced/ |title=Beyond: Two Souls Release Date Announced |publisher=Progress Bar |last=Roberts |first=Brendan |date=4 June 2013 |accessdate=27 June 2013}}</ref><ref name=VG247releasedate>{{cite web |url=https://www.vg247.com/2013/10/08/beyond-two-souls-reviews-for-quantic-dreams-latest-arrive-get-all-the-scores-here/ |title=Beyond: Two Souls - reviews for Quantic Dream's latest arrive, get all the scores here |publisher=[[VG247]] |last=Nunneley |first=Stephany |date=8 October 2013 |accessdate=17 April 2018}}</ref><ref name=IGNreleasedate>{{cite web |url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2013/09/25/gamestop-is-shouting-fans-a-beyond-two-souls-demo-code |title=GameStop is Shouting Fans a Beyond: Two Souls Demo Code |work=[[IGN]] |publisher=[[Ziff Davis]] |last=O'Brien |first=Lucy |date=24 September 2013 |accessdate=17 April 2018}}</ref>
The European version of the game is censored to keep the [[PEGI]] rating at 16 instead of 18. Two changes were made amounting to 5–10 seconds of gameplay.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2013-10-01-sony-confirms-beyond-censored-in-europe |title=Sony confirms Beyond censored in Europe |last=Yin-Poole |first=Wesley |date=1 October 2013 |work=[[Eurogamer]] |publisher=Gamer Network |accessdate=1 October 2013}}</ref>
Immediately after the game was released, nude images of Jodie, actress Ellen Page, surfaced on the [[Reddit]] online community. The game did include one nude scene of Jodie—showering, shown at an angle that preserves the character's modesty—however the leaked images were full-frontal. Industry analysts deduced that a person in possession of a developer PlayStation 3 that allowed [[quality assurance]] features such as "free camera" mode had used the special PlayStation to create and upload the images. Sony immediately took steps to remove them, asking for the community's assistance and explaining that the images were of a digital model and not of Page, who has a "no nudity" policy in titles she appears in. The images were removed from the website.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.inquisitr.com/1003507/ellen-page-nude-beyond-two-souls-leaked-shower-scene-photos/ |title=Ellen Page Nude in Beyond: Two Souls, Sony Objects To Leaked Shower Scene Photos |date=23 October 2013 |work=[[Inquisitr]] |accessdate=28 January 2015}}</ref>
In June 2015, Quantic Dream announced a PlayStation 4 version of ''Beyond: Two Souls'' for North America, Europe, and the PAL region alongside ''Heavy Rain''. The PlayStation 4 version of ''Beyond: Two Souls'' was released on 24 November, with the remaster of ''Heavy Rain'' following on 1 March 2016. A package containing both games was then released physically on a Blu-ray disc.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2015/06/16/beyond-two-souls-and-heavy-rain-are-ps4-bound |title=Beyond: Two Souls and Heavy Rain Are PS4 Bound |work=[[IGN]] |publisher=[[Ziff Davis]] |last=Copeland |first=Wesley |date=16 June 2015 |accessdate=22 June 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://blog.us.playstation.com/2015/11/19/beyond-two-souls-coming-to-ps4-on-nov-24th-heavy-rain-out-next-year/ |title=Beyond: Two Souls Coming to PS4 on Nov. 24th, Heavy Rain Out Next Year |first=Guillaume |last=de Fondaumiere |work=[[PlayStation Blog]] |publisher=[[Sony Interactive Entertainment]] |date=19 November 2015 |accessdate=19 November 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180123181932/https://blog.us.playstation.com/2015/11/19/beyond-two-souls-coming-to-ps4-on-nov-24th-heavy-rain-out-next-year/ |archivedate=23 January 2018}}</ref>
== Reception == {{Video game reviews | MC =(PS4) 72/100<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.metacritic.com/game/playstation-4/beyond-two-souls |title=Beyond: Two Souls for PlayStation 4 Reviews |publisher=[[Metacritic]] |accessdate=20 September 2016}}</ref><br>(PS3) 70/100<ref name="MC">{{cite web |url=http://www.metacritic.com/game/playstation-3/beyond-two-souls |title=Beyond: Two Souls for PlayStation 3 Reviews |publisher=[[Metacritic]] |accessdate=8 October 2013}}</ref> | Destruct = 5/10<ref name="Destructoid">{{cite web |last=Sterling |first=Jim |date=8 October 2013 |url=http://www.destructoid.com/review-beyond-two-souls-263180.phtml |title=Review: Beyond: Two Souls |work=[[Destructoid]] |accessdate=8 October 2013}}</ref> | EGM = 7.5/10<ref name="EGM">{{cite web |last=Harmon |first=Josh |date=8 October 2013 |url=http://www.egmnow.com/articles/reviews/egm-review-beyond-two-souls/ |title=EGM Review: Beyond: Two Souls |work=[[Electronic Gaming Monthly]] |accessdate=8 October 2013}}</ref> | EuroG = 6/10<ref name="EuroG">{{cite web |last=Welsh |first=Oli |date=8 October 2013 |url=http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2013-10-08-beyond-two-souls-review |title=A Flawed Epic – Beyond: Two Souls review |work=[[Eurogamer]] |publisher=Gamer Network |accessdate=8 October 2013}}</ref> | GameRev = {{Rating|4|5}}<ref name="GameRev">{{cite web |last=Tan |first=Nick |date=8 October 2013 |url=http://www.gamerevolution.com/review/61776-beyond-two-souls-review |title=Beyond: Two Souls Review |work=[[Game Revolution]] |accessdate=8 October 2013}}</ref> | GSpot = 9.0/10<ref name="GSpot">{{cite web |last=McShea |first=Tom |date=8 October 2013 |url=http://www.gamespot.com/reviews/beyond-two-souls-review/1900-6415418/ |title=Beyond: Two Souls Review |work=[[GameSpot]] |publisher=[[CBS Interactive]] |accessdate=8 October 2013}}</ref> | GRadar = {{Rating|3.5|5}}<ref name="GRadar">{{cite web |last=Betka |first=Zach |date=8 October 2013 |url=http://www.gamesradar.com/beyond-two-souls-review/ |title=Beyond: Two Souls |work=[[GamesRadar]] |accessdate=8 October 2013}}</ref> | GTM = 8/10<ref name="GTM">{{cite web |url=http://www.gamestm.co.uk/reviews/beyond-two-souls-review/ |title=Beyond: Two Souls Review |work=[[GamesTM]] |date=8 October 2013 |accessdate=8 October 2013}}</ref> | IGN = 6.0/10<ref name="IGN2">{{cite web |last=O'Brien |first=Lucy |date=8 October 2013 |url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2013/10/08/beyond-two-souls-review |title=Beyond: Two Souls for PlayStation 3 Reviews |work=[[IGN]] |publisher=[[Ziff Davis]] |accessdate=8 October 2013}}</ref> | Joystiq = {{Rating|2.5|5}}<ref name="Joystiq">{{cite web |last=Kietzmann |first=Ludwig |date=8 October 2013 |url=https://www.engadget.com/2013/10/08/beyond-two-souls-review-bc07eda2/ |title=Beyond: Two Souls review: Ever Tethered |work=[[Joystiq]] |accessdate=8 October 2013}}</ref> | OPMUK = 8/10<ref name="OPMUK">{{cite web |last=Iwaniuk |first=Phil |date=8 October 2013 |url=http://www.officialplaystationmagazine.co.uk/review/beyond-two-souls-review-official-playstation-magazine/ |title=Beyond: Two Souls review – an essential purchase for interactive-drama fans |work=[[PlayStation Official Magazine - UK|PlayStation Official Magazine]] |accessdate=8 October 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131009132059/http://www.officialplaystationmagazine.co.uk/review/beyond-two-souls-review-official-playstation-magazine/ |archivedate=9 October 2013 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> | Poly = 8.0/10<ref name="Polygon">{{cite web |last=McElroy |first=Justin |date=8 October 2013 |url=http://www.polygon.com/2013/10/8/4814738/beyond-two-souls-review |title=Beyond: Two Souls review: hand in hand |work=[[Polygon (website)|Polygon]] |accessdate=8 October 2013}}</ref> }}
''Beyond: Two Souls'' received polarised reviews upon release.<ref name="IGN3">{{cite web |title=Why is Beyond: Two Souls so polarizing? |url=http://www.ign.com/videos/2013/10/11/ign-au-talks-beyond-two-souls |work=[[IGN]] |publisher=[[Ziff Davis]] |accessdate=13 December 2013}}</ref> Review aggregator [[Metacritic]] described its reception as "mixed".<ref name="MC"/> Critics praised Page's character portrayal of Jodie Holmes and Dafoe's performance as Nathan Dawkins, as well as the amount of technical details in the game's animations and graphics. Praise was also generally given toward the elaborate motion capture, interactive storytelling mechanics, emotional soundtrack, and ability to appeal to non-gamers.<ref name="Forbes2">{{cite web |last=Tassi |first=Paul |date=9 October 2013 |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/insertcoin/2013/10/09/why-we-need-more-games-like-beyond-two-souls/ |title=Why We Need More Games Like ''Beyond: Two Souls'' |work=[[Forbes (magazine)|Forbes]] |accessdate=12 September 2014}}</ref><ref name="theverge.com">{{cite web |last=Hollister |first=Sean |date=8 October 2013 |url=https://www.theverge.com/2013/10/8/4814072/beyond-two-souls-review |title='Beyond: Two Souls' review: crossing the blurry line between movies and games |work=[[The Verge]] |accessdate=12 September 2014}}</ref><ref name="ew.com"/><ref name="GameRev"/> ''[[PlayStation Official Magazine – UK|PlayStation Official Magazine]]'' (UK) spoke frankly of a game using [[quick time event]]s over a more acceptable solution: "you lose explicit control", yet believing ''Beyond'' ultimately wins in ways such as its imagery: "PS3's graphical high point" and Page's performance: "Astonishing ... she's the lynchpin that holds all the madness together with a painfully human presence."<ref name="OPMUK"/> ''[[GameSpot]]'' called the game a "gripping adventure", observing that the gameplay's choices give the player an ability to shape what kind of person Jodie becomes, making us "care dearly for her ... and become enamoured with this young woman and her extraordinary life".<ref name="GSpot"/> ''[[Game Revolution]]'' praised the game as "uncannily gorgeous", confirming Quantic Dream remains a leader in the story-driven genre, calling their high-quality cinematic gameplay "the saving grace of ''Beyond: Two Souls''".<ref name="GameRev"/> The game received positive reviews from the playerbase, scoring an 8.1/10 on Metacritic's user score.<ref name="MC"/>
While ''[[Electronic Gaming Monthly]]'' praised the visuals, the performances, and the "bold, genre-defying design work", it expressed disappointment in Quantic Dream; respecting its years of "audacity" pushing the boundaries of the game medium, yet ultimately failing to listen to feedback and instead delivering yet "another flawed experiment—better in some ways, worse in others".<ref name="EGM"/> ''[[IGN]]'' gaming website criticised the game for offering a gaming experience too passive and unrewarding: "It is unwise to build up our expectations of being able to choose our actions and then take that away from us where it feels most important" and a muddy and unfocused interactive drama "to make gamers conditioned to meaningless violence feel something".<ref name="IGN2"/> ''[[Joystiq]]'' criticised the game's lack of solid character interaction and its unbelievable, unintentionally silly plot.<ref name="Joystiq"/> ''[[Destructoid]]'' criticised the game's thin character presentation and frequent narrative dead ends, as well as its lack of meaningful interactivity.<ref name="Destructoid"/> The editor of ''[[Eurogamer]]'' took issue with the "gruelling, sentimental" game being "all story", comparing it to other games that "give the player complete control", observing the triviality of the player choices may modify the tone of each self-contained chapter, but the overall story is "going wherever it's going".<ref name="EuroG"/> ''[[GamesRadar+]]'' liked the game, but warned "you'll never be truly challenged by the gameplay".<ref name="GRadar"/> Entertainer [[Ben "Yahtzee" Croshaw]] of ''[[Zero Punctuation]]'' was heavily critical of the game, focusing on the overuse of quick time events, the underuse of the game's central stealth mechanics, and the inconsistent tone and atmosphere, comparing playing the game to "watching any normal film and pressing the pause button every two seconds".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.escapistmagazine.com/videos/view/zero-punctuation/8298-Beyond-Two-Souls |title=Beyond: Two Souls |last=Croshaw |first=Ben |date=23 October 2013 |work=[[The Escapist (magazine)|The Escapist]] |accessdate=8 October 2014}}</ref>
=== Awards === At [[Spike (TV channel)|Spike]]'s [[Spike Video Game Awards|Video Game Awards]] show, ''Beyond: Two Souls'' earned two nominations: Best Voice Actress (Ellen Page)<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.spike.com/vgx/best-voice-actress |title=Spike VGX: Best Voice Actress |work=[[VGX (award show)|VGX]] |publisher=[[Spike (TV network)|Spike]] |accessdate=7 November 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131211101300/http://www.spike.com/vgx/best-voice-actress |archivedate=11 December 2013 |deadurl=no}}</ref> and Best Voice Actor (Willem Dafoe).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.spike.com/vgx/best-voice-actor |title=Spike VGX: Best Voice Actor |work=[[VGX (award show)|VGX]] |publisher=[[Spike (TV network)|Spike]] |accessdate=7 November 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131207055142/http://www.spike.com/vgx/best-voice-actor |archivedate=7 December 2013 |deadurl=no}}</ref>
The [[10th British Academy Games Awards|British Academy of Film and Television Arts]] (BAFTA) nominated the game for Best Artistic Achievement (John Rostron, David Cage, Guillaume De Fondaumiere), Best Original Music (Lorne Balfe), and Best Performer (Ellen Page).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://awards.bafta.org/award/2014/games |title=BAFTA: Games in 2014 |date=12 March 2014 |publisher=British Academy of Film and Television Arts |accessdate=7 November 2014}}</ref>
At the 2013 [[National Academy of Video Game Trade Reviewers]] Awards, ''Beyond: Two Souls'' won Game, Original Adventure and was nominated for Lead Performance in a Drama, Supporting Performance in a Drama, Writing in a Drama, Camera Direction in a Game Engine, Animation, Control Design (3D), Graphics (Technical), Lighting/Texturing, and Use of Sound (New IP).<ref>{{cite web |title=NAVGTR Awards (2013) |url=http://navgtr.org/archives/2028 |work=[[National Academy of Video Game Trade Reviewers]] |date=17 February 2014}}</ref>
At the 2012 [[Game Critics Awards]] event, the game was nominated for Best Original Game and Best Action/Adventure Game,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.gamecriticsawards.com/2012nominees.html |title=Game Critics Awards |work=Game Critics Awards |access-date=13 June 2018}}</ref> and the next year, it also earned a nomination for Best Console Game.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.polygon.com/2013/6/26/4465446/game-critics-awards-announces-best-of-e3-2013-nominees-titanfall |title=Game Critics Awards announces Best of E3 2013 nominees, Titanfall dominates |work=[[Polygon (website)|Polygon]] |date=26 June 2013 |access-date=13 June 2018}}</ref> At the 17th Annual [[D.I.C.E. Awards]], it was nominated for three categories: Outstanding Achievement in Story, Outstanding Achievement in Animation and Outstanding Achievement in Original Music Composition.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://nerdist.com/your-17th-annual-dice-awards-nominees/ |title=Your 17th Annual DICE Awards Nominees |work=[[The Nerdist]] |date=16 January 2014 |access-date=13 June 2018}}</ref> At the [[18th Satellite Awards]], ''Beyond: Two Souls'' was nominated for Outstanding Action/Adventure Video Game.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.thewrap.com/12-years-slave-tops-satellite-award-nominations/ |title=''12 Years a Slave'' Tops Satellite Award Nominations |work=[[The Wrap]] |date=2 December 2013 |access-date=13 June 2018}}</ref>
=== Sales === It was reported in July 2013 that ''Beyond: Two Souls'' was in the top twenty most pre-ordered games of 2013,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.computerandvideogames.com/421440/call-of-duty-ghosts-leading-software-preorder-sales-analyst/ |title=Call of Duty: Ghosts leading software preorder sales - analyst |last=Prescott |first=Shaun |date=29 July 2013 |work=[[Computer and Video Games]] |accessdate=7 November 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131007003932/http://www.computerandvideogames.com/421440/call-of-duty-ghosts-leading-software-preorder-sales-analyst/ |archivedate=7 October 2013}}</ref> and that by the end 2013, the game sold one million copies worldwide during its first three months of availability.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.engadget.com/2014/01/10/beyond-two-souls-sales-topped-1-million-in-2013 |title=Beyond Two Souls-sales topped 1 million in 2013 |first=David |last=Hinkle |date=October 1, 2014 |accessdate=October 1, 2014 | publisher=[[Eurogamer|GamesIndustry.biz]]}}</ref> The game sold over 70,000 copies in Quantic Dream's home country France during that time, more than its previous game ''Heavy Rain'' during its three-month debut.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.gamespot.com/articles/ps3-game-beyond-two-souls-sold-1-million-copies-in-2013/1100-6417065/ |title=PS3 game Beyond: Two Souls sold 1 million copies in 2013 |last=Makuch |first=Eddie |date=10 January 2014 |work=[[GameSpot]] |publisher=[[CBS Interactive]] |accessdate=10 January 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.engadget.com/2014/01/10/beyond-two-souls-sales-topped-1-million-in-2013/ |title=Beyond: Two Souls sales topped 1 million in 2013 |date=February 2013 |work=[[Joystiq]] |accessdate=1 June 2013}}</ref> ''Heavy Rain''{{'s}} budget was $22 million and the budget for ''Beyond: Two Souls'' was $27 million, not including approximately $18 million in costs for marketing and distribution.<ref>{{cite web |last=Makuch |first=Eddie |url=http://www.gamespot.com/articles/beyond-two-souls-budget-was-27-million-report/1100-6414844/ |title=Beyond: Two Souls budget was $27 million - Report |work=[[GameSpot]] |publisher=[[CBS Interactive]] |date=23 September 2013 |accessdate=28 January 2015}}</ref> ''Beyond: Two Souls'' reached 2.8 million copies sold by the time Quantic Dream's next title was released in 2018, becoming one of the [[List of best-selling PlayStation 3 video games|best-selling PlayStation 3 video games]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://gamingbolt.com/beyond-two-souls-sold-2-8-million-copies |title=Beyond: Two Souls Has Sold 2.8 Million Copies Worldwide |date=16 July 2018 |work=GamingBolt |accessdate=20 July 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.gamereactor.eu/news/679883/Beyond+Two+Souls+reportedly+sold+28+million+copies+so+far/ |title=Beyond: Two Souls reportedly sold 2.8 million copies so far |first=David |last=Caballero |date=16 July 2018 |website=[[Gamereactor]] |archivedate=17 August 2018 |archiveurl=http://archive.today/2018.08.17-213749/https://www.gamereactor.eu/news/679883/Beyond+Two+Souls+reportedly+sold+28+million+copies+so+far/ |deadurl=no}}</ref>
=== Legacy === In November 2014, David Cage discussed the future of video games and referred to the generally negative reviews ''Beyond'' received from [[Gamer#Hardcore gamer|hardcore gamer]]s. "There will always be games for the hardcore gamers who see games as a skill-based sport, or as a way to compete with their friends", he said. He also referred to [[casual game]]rs who play games "as a mere hobby, like many titles for smartphones". He then stated, "We try to develop a middle way, with games that try to tell a story, to carry meaning, and where violence isn't the core activity. Most of all, we try to create an emotion, to make players live something strong and unique, which remains an ambitious challenge in a video game."<ref>{{cite web |last=Riaz |first=Adnan |url=http://www.gamerheadlines.com/2014/11/david-cage-working-something-exciting/ |title=David Cage: "We're Working on Something Very Exciting" |publisher=Gamer Headlines |date=28 November 2014 |accessdate=28 January 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170628150039/http://www.gamerheadlines.com/2014/11/david-cage-working-something-exciting/ |archivedate=28 June 2017}}</ref>
{{-}}
