page.title: Biennale Internationale des Arts du Cirque

revision.comment: standard quote handling in WP;standard Apostrophe/quotation marks in WP; MOS general fixes
revision.text:
The "Biennale Internationale des Arts du Cirque" is the largest contemporary circus festival in the world and is held in the south of France every two years. The Biennale is organised by the [[Archaos]] circus company and the first edition in 2015 attracted 60 circus companies from around the world and had more than 85,000 visitors.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lci.fr/france/marseille-capitale-internationale-du-cirque-1518985.html|title=Marseille, capitale internationale du cirque|publisher=}}</ref>
==History==
The Archaos circus company is one of the legendary contemporary circus companies in Europe. Their work in Britain changed the way the circus was seen and the founder of Archaos, [[Pierrot Bidon]], was seen as a circus revolutionary. In Bidon's obituary in [[The Guardian]], Archaos was described as "one of the ensembles that galvanised the new circus movement, in which traditional arts have been re-imagined and combined with contemporary artistic sensibilities and theatrical techniques."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/stage/2010/mar/21/pierrot-bidon-obituary|title=Pierrot Bidon obituary|first=Mark|last=Borkowski|date=21 March 2010|website=the Guardian}}</ref>
The Biennale itself was born out of the Circus in Capitals project that Archaos managed as part of [[Marseille-Provence 2013]], the European Capital of Culture festivities. The success of the circus arts during the Marseille Provence 2013 inspired the Archaos company to create the first Biennale Internationale des Arts du Cirque in 2015. The first biennale featured circus companies such as [[Nofit State Circus]], [[Cirque Éloize]], and the [[Chinese State Circus]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lamarseillaise.fr/culture/danse/35292-la-grande-parade-du-cirque|title=La grande parade de la Biennale des arts du cirque - Journal La Marseillaise|first=Catherine|last=Walgenwitz|publisher=}}</ref>
The first Biennale was such a success that in 2016 the company created the L'Entre–Deux Biennales to meet public demand and continue to foster the circus arts in years when the Biennale was not being held. Archaos was nominated for the Best Producer award for the L'Entre-Deux Biennales project at the 2016 Annual International Professional Circus Awards in Sochi, Russia that were organised by the Russian Ministry of Culture. Archaos was also chosen to present performances at the Club France that was held during the Rio Olympics in August 2016.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.telerama.fr/monde/a-rio-les-pays-soignent-leurs-facades-dans-leurs-maisons-olympiques,146115.php|title=A Rio, les pays soignent leurs façades dans leurs maisons olympiques|publisher=}}</ref>
==2017 Biennale==
The second edition of the Biennale ran from January 21 to February 19, 2017. It featured more than 260 performances in close to 30 cities in the south of France including [[Marseille]], [[Aix-en-Provence]], [[Grasse]], and [[Gap, Hautes-Alpes|Gap]]. The 2017 Biennale included new work from leading British companies NoFit State Circus and [[Motionhouse]], the Swedish company [[Cirkus Cirkör]], and the Brazilian company Borogodo. More than 120,000 people attended events.
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.biennale-cirque.com/en/ "Biennale de Cirque website] {{en icon}} * [http://www.archaos.fr/rep/ "Archaos website] {{fr icon}}

revision.comment: Robot - Moving category United States Marine Corps in video games‎ to [[:Category:Video games about the United States Marine Corps]] per [[WP:CFD|CFD]] at [[Wikipedia:Categories for discussion/Log/2018 October 23]].
revision.text:
{{refimprove|date=January 2009}} {{Infobox video game |title = CTU: Marine Sharpshooter |image = |developer = Jarhead Games |publisher = Groove Games |engine = [[Lithtech#Talon|Lithtech Talon]] |platforms = [[Microsoft Windows|Windows]], [[iOS]] |released = March 20, 2003 |genre = [[First-person shooter]] |modes = [[Single-player]] |director = Alan Freemantle |producer = |designer = |programmer = John Twigg
Jason Verhiel |artist = Tyler Wilson |writer = |composer = Brian Youds }} '''''CTU: Marine Sharpshooter''''' is a [[first-person shooter]] [[video game]] developed by [[Jarhead Games]] and published by [[Groove Games]], released March 20, 2003. A sequel, ''[[Marine Sharpshooter II: Jungle Warfare]]'', was released in 2004. It was published on iOS by Groove Games, and was acquired by [[XMG Studio]] on March 22, 2010. On iOS, the game hit number one in multiple countries, and has been downloaded over a million times.{{cite web |author=Dan Kricke |url=http://www.appolicious.com/articles/2788-marine-sharpshooter-iphone-game-just-misses-the-mark |title=Marine Sharpshooter iPhone game just misses the mark - iPhone app review - Dan Kricke | Appolicious ™ iPhone and iPad App Directory |publisher=Appolicious.com |date=2010-08-15 |accessdate=2012-08-17 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120330200004/http://www.appolicious.com/articles/2788-marine-sharpshooter-iphone-game-just-misses-the-mark |archivedate=2012-03-30 |df= }} ==Plot== ''CTU: Marine Sharpshooter'''s story details the adventures of [[Lieutenant]] Smith and [[Sergeant]] Cooper, a [[United States Marine Corps|US Marine Corps]] [[Scout Sniper|scout sniper]], team as they chase down some warlords in Afghanistan and follow the trail of lost nuclear materials. The player assumes the role of the [[sniper]], as you take on an army of terrorists and mercenaries in order to prevent [[nuclear holocaust]]. ==Gameplay== ''CTU: Marine Sharpshooter'''s gameplay involves both sniping and [[close combat]]. The main shooting mechanic is sniping, with the ability to use the sniper rifle's scope to zoom in on far away targets. Close combat is done with a pistol with an optional [[Suppressor|silencer]], or a knife. Several points in the game require the player to stay in one spot engaging hostiles that emerge from various doorways and windows. At other times, the player can explore the map freely. The game features simulations of the [[sniper rifles]] used by the US Marine Corps [[snipers]], as well as other real weapons, such as [[assault rifles]], [[pistols]], and [[sniper rifles]]. There is even the occasional [[Rocket-propelled grenade|RPG]] used by the enemy. The game's environment varies from the caves and small villages of [[Afghanistan]], to the snowy cliffs and rooftops of [[Chechnya]], to sandy beaches and jungles of Pacific island. Interaction between player and environment is minimal. The game features a semi-intelligent spotter, who can be set to follow you or hold position, and "hold fire" or "fire at will". The spotter call out the compass heading of the direction that enemies are in as they come within a certain range. The spotter can also assist the player in engaging enemies. You fail a mission if the spotter dies or if you die. The game features a few first-aid kits as standard inventory, which will patch you up a little after taking hits. Your spotter has his own kits, and he will use them during lulls in fighting. You cannot patch him up, nor vice versa. There are also no further kits or ammunition available within the mission. However, small quantities of ammunition can be obtained from the sniper rifles you pick up from dead enemies. ==Reception== ''CTU: Marine Sharpshooter'' was poorly received,{{cite web|url=http://pc.ign.com/objects/545/545778.html |title=CTU: Marine Sharpshooter - PC - IGN |publisher=Pc.ign.com |date=2003-04-08 |accessdate=2012-08-17}} with a score on IGN of 4.1 (bad) and the reviewer, calling it a "rehash" and an "impersonator" of better titles.{{cite web|url=http://pc.ign.com/articles/392/392767p1.html |title=CTU Marine Sharpshooter - PC Review at IGN |publisher=Pc.ign.com |date=2003-04-07 |accessdate=2012-08-17}} ==Sequel== '''''Marine Sharpshooter 2: Jungle Warfare''''' is a sequel to ''CTU: Marine Sharpshooter'' published in June 24 2004.http://www.gamefaqs.com/pc/920060-marine-sharpshooter-ii-jungle-warfare/data Deployed into one of Africa's most dangerous countries, the objective of the game is to find the President of [[Burundi]] and rescue him from heavily armed rebels and the ruthless mercenaries who back them. If the rebels are not stopped and the President dies, they will plunge the region into a brutal civil war. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.gamespot.com/pc/action/marinesharpshooter/index.html GameSpot] *[http://www.mobygames.com/game/windows/ctu-marine-sharpshooter MobyGames Page] [[Category:First-person shooters]] [[Category:IOS games]] [[Category:Lithtech engine games]] [[Category:Windows games]] [[Category:2003 video games]] [[Category:Propaganda video games]] [[Category:Sniper video games]] [[Category:Video games about the United States Marine Corps]] [[Category:Video games developed in Canada]] [[Category:Video games set in Afghanistan]] [[Category:Video games set in Chechnya]] [[Category:Video games set in Burundi]]

revision.text:
A '''conditional joke''' is a [[joke]] meant for a qualified audience only, possessing prior knowledge and understanding of the topic, which in turn enables them to understand the joke. Such ability is also called the prerequisite condition for laughter. The conditional joke is one of two main categories of jokes, according to Ted Cohen; the main one being a universal joke, which does not require familiarity with the hermetic language of a conditional joke.<ref name="Cohen">{{cite book |author=Ted Cohen|url=https://books.google.ca/books?id=eIPSME0a35QC&q=Conditional |title=Jokes: Philosophical Thoughts on Joking Matters |page=12, 21 |year=1999 |publisher=University of Chicago Press |ISBN=0-226-11230-6}}</ref> The conditional, or ''hermetic'' jokes, often depend on the internalized negative stereotypes held by the audience toward a targeted group of people. Such affective disposition can also explain the persistence of [[ethnic jokes]] in multicultural societies. Although they can be understood by many, the conditional jokes usually don't make ridiculed individuals [[laugh]] at the [[punch line]].<ref name="Cohen"/><ref name="Capps">{{cite book |author=Donald Capps |title=A Time to Laugh: The Religion of Humor |pages=67–69 |url=https://books.google.ca/books?id=eqDnRRdF53QC&q=conditional |publisher=A&C Black |year=2006 |ISBN=0826418570}}</ref>
The most common type of conditional jokes, which target the jargon and all topics specific to professions and occupations, include the doctor jokes (surgeons, internists, psychiatrists, etc.), the lawyers and politicians, musicians, and the rabbi jokes among many. Other ''hermetic'' jokes which target ethnicity include [[Polish joke]]s made in the US, [[Irish jokes]] made in England, Ukrainian jokes made in Russia, [[Newfie]] jokes made in Canada, [[Sardarji joke]]s made in India, [[Russian jokes]] about ethnicities, Texas jokes, Jewish jokes made by non-Jews, the Black people jokes, and numerous others.<ref name="Cohen78">{{cite book |author=Ted Cohen |url=https://books.google.ca/books?id=ogEPRnVpx4wC&q=negative+beliefs |title=Jokes: Philosophical Thoughts on Joking Matters |page=78 |year=1999}}</ref>
==See also== * [[In-joke]] * [[Ethnic stereotype]] * [[An Englishman, an Irishman and a Scotsman]] * [[Stereotype]]
== References == {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Jokes| ]] [[Category:Humour]] [[Category:Traditional stories]] [[Category:Jokes based on national and racial stereotypes]] [[Category:Ethnic humour]]

'''Dallas Barr''' is a [[comic book]] series (or "[[graphic novel]]") by [[Belgium|Belgian]] artist [[Marvano]] (Mark van Oppen) adapted from [[United States of America|American]] [[science fiction]] author [[Joe Haldeman]]'s 1989 novel ''Buying Time''. The protagonist, Dallas Barr, is 132 years old. The series takes place around 2075, in a world where a prolonged life is available to the ultrarich through the Stileman Procedure, where the moon is a colony and AIDS-X is rampant. The series ran from 1996 to 2005.
Although the first comic in the series clearly draws on Joe Haldeman's ''Buying Time'' ( UK title: ''The Long Habit of Living''), the plots of the following volumes continue beyond the end of the original novel. The plots of the continuation were written by Haldeman in English, translated into French by Marvano. The later volumes are written by Marvano alone, as Haldeman found him to do a good job. In the series the author challenges the reader to reflect on the issues at hand. Politics, philosophy and humanity's stupidity are often given a chance in this series. Over the years, the plot got more complicated and the characters came to their full potential, while at the same time its philosophical considerations deepened.
==External links== * [http://www.bedetheque.com/serie-90-BD-Dallas-Barr.html Dallas Barr page]

revision.text:
The '''Film Quota Act''', full title the '''New South Wales Cinematograph Films (Australian Quota) Act''' was an act of legislation passed in September 1935 that came into force on 1 January 1936. Under the Act it was compulsory that in the first year of operation 5 per cent, of the films distributed in New South Wales must be Australian productions, the percentage to increase yearly for five years when it becomes 15 per cent.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article17321184 |title=Advertising. |newspaper=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]] |date=27 May 1936 |accessdate=12 August 2012 |page=15 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref>
The Act was introduced at the behest of New South Wales' Premier [[Bertram Stevens (politician)|Bertram Stevens]]. Its ultimate impact turned out to be limited due to a loophole in the legislation. The use of the word "acquire" meant it was considered that the act was drafted to reflect exhibition of films, not ensure production; distributors argued they had no obligation to produce movies.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article17292728 |title=FILM QUOTA. |newspaper=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]] |date=30 December 1936 |accessdate=12 August 2012 |page=7 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref> Some American distributors made veiled threats to remove Hollywood films from exhibition.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article27986942 |title=THE FILM QUOTA. |newspaper=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]] |date=1 April 1937 |accessdate=12 August 2012 |page=8 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref><ref>[http://lantern.mediahist.org/catalog/variety117-1935-03_0140]</ref>
In 1937 the New South Wales government decided not to force distributors to participate in production. Similar legislation was passed in Victoria but was never proclaimed. By the end of the decade the quota law had ceased to operate in practice.<ref>[http://afcarchive.screenaustralia.gov.au/downloads/policies/early%20history_final1.pdf Early history of Australian Film, ''Screen Australia''] accessed 24 August 2014</ref>
==See also== *[[Screen quotas]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.austlii.edu.au/au/legis/nsw/num_act/cfqa1935n41394.pdf Copy of Act]
[[Category:Cinema of Australia]] [[Category:New South Wales legislation]] [[Category:1935 in Australian law]] [[Category:20th century in New South Wales]] [[Category:Quotas]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox person | name = Frank Dumont | image =Frank_Dumont.jpg | image_size = | caption = | birth_date = January 25, 1848 | birth_place = [[Utica, New York]] | death_date = {{d-da|March 17, 1919|January 25, 1848}} | death_place = [[Philadelphia]], [[Pennsylvania]] | occupation = Minstrel show performer and manager | spouse = | parents = | children = }}
'''Frank Dumont''' (January 25, 1848 – March 17, 1919) was an [[United States|American]] [[minstrel show]] performer and manager.<ref name="monarch1">Rice, Edward Le Roy. [https://books.google.com/books?id=nvY5AAAAIAAJ&pg=PA198&dq=#v=onepage&q&f=false Monarchs of minstrelsy, from "Daddy" Rice to date], p. 198 (1911)</ref><ref name="findingaid">[http://www.hsp.org/sites/www.hsp.org/files/migrated/findingaid3054dumont.pdf Finding Aid: Collection 3054 - Frank Dumont (1848-1919) - Minstrelsy Scrapbook], by the [[Historical Society of Pennsylvania]] (2004)</ref><ref name="obit1">(17 March 1919). [http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83045211/1919-03-17/ed-1/seq-1/ Frank Dumont, Noted Minstrel, Dies At Theatre], [[Public Ledger (Philadelphia)|Evening Public Ledger]]''</ref>
==Life== Dumont was born in [[Utica, New York]] on January 25, 1848. He started performing in minstrel shows as early as 1862, and worked with a number of groups, including [[Duprez & Benedict's Minstrels]] from about 1869 to 1881. He eventually founded "Dumont's Minstrels", around 1895/96, after purchasing the Eleventh Street Opera House in Philadelphia. He authored many sketches and songs for the genre. One [[afterpiece]] he wrote was later expanded into a successful 1884 play, ''[[A Parlor Match]]''.
After the Opera House closed circa 1909, Dumont acquired Dime Museum at Ninth and Arch Streets and renamed it "Dumont's Theatre".<ref name="another">[http://www.ulib.niu.edu/badndp/dumont_frank.html Frank Dumont], Northern Illinois University Libraries -- House of Beadle & Adams Online -- The Authors and Their Novels, Retrieved November 3, 2011</ref> He died in the box office of the theatre on March 17, 1919 during the opening number of that afternoon's matinee show.<ref name="obit1"/><ref name="widowobit">(26 May 1939) [https://www.nytimes.com/1939/05/26/archives/obituary-1-no-title.html Mrs. Frank Dumont (obituary)], ''[[The New York Times]]''</ref><ref name="dimeburns">(26 February 1929). [https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=OChaAAAAIBAJ&sjid=5ksNAAAAIBAJ&pg=1300,5133242&dq= Noted Shrine of Minstrelsy Ends Career], ''Providence News'' (noting fire that burned down Dumont's Theatre, 1929)</ref>
Dumont's 1899 work "The Witmark amateur minstrel guide and burnt cork encyclopedia" is a valuable resource on the history of American minstrelsy. [[Image:Frank Dumont 1899.jpg|thumb|left|250px|Dumont, from ''The Witmark amateur minstrel guide and burnt cork encyclopedia'' (1899)]]
Dumont wrote in 1915 that he had been the first to perform two classic 19th century standards, "[[Silver Threads Among the Gold]]", and "[[When You and I Were Young, Maggie]]".<ref name="cir1">Dumont, Frank (27 March 1915). [http://www.circushistory.org/Cork/BurntCork6.htm The Younger Generation in Minstrelsy and Reminiscences of the Past], ''[[New York Clipper]]'' ("Dumont was the first to sing "Silver Threads Among the Gold," for whom it was written by H. P. Danks. He also first introduced "When You and I Were Young, Maggie" as the Duprez & Benedict’s Minstrels programs, dated, will show and the still living members of that celebrated troupe remember well.")</ref>
[[Pat Chappelle]] commissioned Dumont in 1900 to write ''A Rabbit's Foot'', a comedy-based show that became a hit and led to the creation of Chappelle's "[[Rabbit's Foot Company|Rabbit's Foot (Comedy) Company]]."<ref>"Rabbit's Foot Comedy Company; T. G. Williams; William Mosely; Ross Jackson; Sam Catlett; Mr. Chappelle" News/Opinion, ''The Freeman'' page 6. October 7, 1905. Indianapolis, Indiana</ref> Chappelle was the first black owner of a vaudeville company with an all-black cast, and utilized upscale performers that helped him dominate the southwest and southeastern areas of the U.S. and also traveled to [[New Jersey]], New York, [[Washington, D.C.]], and [[Baltimore]].<ref>"The Stage." News/Opinion (Lakeview, NJ opening), ''The Freeman'', page 5. March 9, 1900. Indianapolis, Indiana</ref><ref name=abbott>[https://books.google.com/books?id=u4rc-BKNCyoC&pg=PA248&lpg=PA248&dq=%22Pat+Chappelle%22&source=bl&ots=7u2N8ttCNC&sig=oCXpr-sKQPAmiNmKxyEBHIHw--s&hl=en&sa=X&ei=fk-4U9-UJPLP0AWP5oDQDw&ved=0CCQQ6AEwATgK#v=onepage&q=%22Pat%20Chappelle%22&f=false Lynn Abbott, Doug Seroff, ''Ragged But Right: Black Traveling Shows, Coon Songs, and the Dark Pathway to Blues and Jazz''], Univ. Press of Mississippi, 2009, pp.248-289</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * Dumont, Frank. [https://books.google.com/books?id=Hf8yAQAAIAAJ&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false The Witmark Amateur Minstrel Guide and Burnt Cork Encyclopedia] (1899) (full copy online) * The [http://www.hsp.org/files/findingaid3054dumont.pdf Frank Dumont Minstrelsy Scrapbook 1850-1902], containing more than 50 years of documentation about minstrelsy and its origins, is available for research use at the [[Historical Society of Pennsylvania]]. * [http://www.circushistory.org/Cork/BurntCork6.htm The Younger Generation in Minstrelsy and Reminiscences of the Past], by Frank Dumont, ''New York Clipper'', March 27, 1915
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Dumont, Frank}} [[Category:Blackface minstrel performers]] [[Category:1848 births]] [[Category:1919 deaths]] [[Category:19th-century American singers]]

[[CNN en Español]]
[[CNN Chile]] | timeshift names = | web = [http://isat.tv Latin America]
[http://canalisat.com.br Brazil] | terr serv 1 = | terr chan 1 = | sat serv 1 = [[DirecTV]] (Latin America) | sat chan 1 = Channel 520 | cable serv 1 = | cable chan 1 = | sat radio serv 1 = | sat radio chan 1 = | adsl serv 1 = | adsl chan 1 = | online serv 1 = | online chan 1 = | 3gmobile serv 1 = }} '''I.Sat''' (contraction of the [[Spanish language|Spanish]] phrase ''Imagen Satelital'', which means "[[Satellite]] image") is an [[Argentina|Argentine]] [[cable television]] channel owned by [[Turner Broadcasting System Latin America]] and [[AT&T]]'s [[WarnerMedia]]. It airs movies, series, music and shows focused on people aged 18 to 39. It is headquartered in [[Buenos Aires]], [[Argentina]]. It is broadcast on the [[satellite]] [[Intelsat 21]] and is broadcast by most [[cable television]] companies in [[Argentina]], [[Brazil]], [[Bolivia]], [[Chile]], [[Colombia]], [[Ecuador]], [[Mexico]], [[Panama]], [[Paraguay]], [[Peru]], [[Uruguay]] and [[Venezuela]]. The channel has a dedicated feed for Argentina, Uruguay and Paraguay, and until November 2012, a dedicated feed for Brazil, which is now covered by the channel's pan-regional feed. ==History== Until 2007, the channel was owned by "Claxson Interactive Group Latin America & Iberia" (which was a subsidiary of the Venezuelan-based [[Grupo Cisneros]]) but that year the channel, along with [[Retro (TV channel)|Retro]] and Space, is bought by [[Turner Broadcasting System]]. It aired different programming on different blocks, such as "Primer Plano I.Sat" (foreign movies), "Cine Argentino Independiente" (independent [[Argentina|Argentine]] films), "Asian Connection" ([[Asia]]n films), and "Cortos I-Sat" (short films). In 2007 it changed its programming from being a 24-hour movies channel to have movies, series, shows, documentary series, music and some others. Some current programming includes ''[[Little Britain]]'', ''[[Raising Hope]]'', ''[[Misfits (TV series)|Misfits]]'', and others. [[Adult Swim]], which previously aired on [[Cartoon Network (Latin America)|Cartoon Network]], aired every night with adult animation series since 2008 after its cancellation from Cartoon Network; however, the Adult Swim block was cancelled from I.Sat on 2011 due to low ratings.[http://www.anmtvla.com/2009/11/isat-extinge-adult-swim-para-siempre.html I.Sat extingue Adult Swim para siempre][http://www.anmtvla.com/2010/11/diciembre-en-isat-ultimo-mes-de-adult.html Diciembre en I.Sat: Último mes de [Adult Swim] Adult Swim however returned to I.Sat on April 3, 2015.http://www.anmtvla.com/2015/02/adult-swim-regresa-en-abril-por-isat.html ==Logos== {| border="0" cellpadding="2" cellspacing="1" style="border:1px solid #aaa" |- align=center !height="150px" bgcolor="#F9F9F9" | [[Image:LogoIsatAnt.gif|100px]] !height="150px" bgcolor="#F9F9F9" | [[Image:ISat.svg|100px]] !height="150px" bgcolor="#F9F9F9" | [[Image:I.Sat logo.svg|100px]] |- !width="150px" colspan="1" bgcolor="#CCCCCC" | 5.09.1993-09.1999 !width="150px" colspan="1" bgcolor="#CCCCCC" | 09.1999-22.03.2010 !width="150px" colspan="1" bgcolor="#CCCCCC" | 23.03.2010-08.06.2018 |} ==Programming== ===Current programming blocks=== *''Asian Connection'': [[Asia]]n films. *''BritTV'': [[United Kingdom|British]] shows and series from [[BBC]] and [[Channel 4]]. *''Cine Argentino Independiente'': [[Argentina|Argentine]] [[independent film]]s. *''Cortos I.Sat'': [[Short films]]. *''I.Films'': Featured movies with monthly premieres. *''I.Series'': Series, shows and reality series. *''Primer Plano I-Sat'': International [[Independent film]]s. *''[[Adult Swim]]'': Previously aired on [[Cartoon Network (Latin America)|Cartoon Network]]. It aired [[cartoons]] and [[anime]] series for adults since 2008. Discontinued in 2011. Returned in April 2015. *''Furia Oriental'': Anime series and Asian films. === Former programming blocks === *''Comedy Central''. Programming block with series from the TV channel [[Comedy Central]]. Discontinued in 2004. *''Cine Zeta''. Films with poor ratings or reviews. Discontinued in 2005. *''Sexorama''. [[Softcore pornography|Softcore]] [[film]]s. Discontinued in 2008. *''Cuentos de terror''. Terror stories narrated by [[Alberto Laiseca]]. Discontinued in 2008. ===Foreign programming=== *[[Adventure Time]] (Lasted only two hours in the special "Happybirthday Cartoon Network") *[[Angel (1999 TV series)|Angel]] *[[Arrested Development (TV series)|Arrested Development]] *[[As If (British TV series)|As If]] *[[Black Mirror]] *[[Buffy the Vampire Slayer (TV series)|Buffy the Vampire Slayer]] *[[Californication (TV series)|Episodes]] *[[Extras (TV series)|Extras]] *[[Late Night with Conan O'Brien]] *[[Little Britain]] *[[Loaded (Fuse TV series)|Loaded]] *[[MADtv]] *[[Neon Genesis Evangelion]] *[[Peep Show (TV revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=December 2014}} {{Infobox person | name = John Scarne | image = The magician John Scarne.png | caption = | birth_name = Orlando Carmelo Scarnecchia | birth_date = {{birth date|1903|03|04}} | birth_place = [[Steubenville, Ohio]], United States | death_date = {{death date and age|1985|07|07|1903|03|04}} | death_place = [[North Bergen, New Jersey]], United States | occupation = [[Magic (illusion)|Magician]], writer }}
'''John Scarne''' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|s|k|ɑr|n|i}}; March 4, 1903 – July 7, 1985) was an American [[Magic (illusion)|magician]] and book author who was particularly adept at [[playing card]] manipulation. He became known as an expert on cards and other games, and authored a number of popular books on cards, [[gambling]], and related topics.
==Early life== He was born '''Orlando Carmelo Scarnecchia''' in [[Steubenville, Ohio]] in the United States of America, and at some point [[anglicize]]d his name to '''John Scarne'''. He grew up in the [[New Jersey]] communities of [[Fairview, Bergen County, New Jersey|Fairview]] and [[Guttenberg, New Jersey|Guttenberg]].<ref name=NYTObit>Cook, John. [https://select.nytimes.com/search/restricted/article?res=F20717F63D5C0C7A8CDDAE0894DD484D81 "JOHN SCARNE, GAMBLING EXPERT"], ''[[The New York Times]]'', July 9, 1985. Accessed January 16, 2008.</ref> When he left school after the eighth grade, he learned from a local [[card sharp]] how to perform such [[confidence trick|swindles]] as [[Three-card Monte|The Three Card Monte]], and how to cheat in [[gamble|gambling]] [[card game]]s by manipulating the cards.<ref name="OddsAgainstMe-3CardMonte">{{cite book | last = Scarne | first = John | title = The Odds Against Me | publisher = Simon & Schuster | year = 1966 | location = New York | pages = 20–34 }}</ref> Scarne began practicing [[sleight of hand]] with the goal of becoming a card sharp, but his [[Catholicism|Roman Catholic]] mother dissuaded her son from gambling in general, and cheating others in particular. She persuaded him to practice magic instead. Scarne soon extended his skill at handling cards to learning—and devising—[[Card magic|magical effects with cards]]. He spent a few months learning about crooked gambling devices (including [[card marking|marked cards]] and [[loaded dice]]) at a nearby novelty store.<ref name="OddsAgainstMe-GamblingDevices">{{cite book | last = Scarne | first = John | title = The Odds Against Me | publisher = Simon & Schuster | year = 1966 | location = New York | pages = 40–71 }}</ref> Thanks to his endless practice, Scarne began making money as a magician.
==Career== Gradually, Scarne became quite an expert at not only [[Magic (illusion)|magical effects]], but games of all kinds as well. Articles were written about him in various magazines, and he was hired as a consultant or adviser by various companies, as well as by the US Army, which sent him to bases around the world in order to educate soldiers about the dangers of card and dice cheats. He wrote fifteen books and co-wrote a few more for a total of twenty-eight books on games, such as ''Scarne on Dice'', ''Scarne's Guide to Modern Poker'' and ''Scarne's New Complete Guide to Gambling''. He also wrote two autobiographies: ''The Amazing World of John Scarne: A Personal History'' (1956), and ''[[The Odds Against Me]]'' (1966). He served as a [[technical advisor]] in the 1973 motion picture, ''[[The Sting]]'', and doubled for actor [[Paul Newman]]'s hands during scenes that involved [[card manipulation]]s and deck switching.
Scarne was often proclaimed by experts, magicians and editors of the time as the greatest card manipulator of all time. But he was happiest when inventing (and marketing, through his company John Scarne Games, Inc.) new games, which he did quite a bit. And he was especially proud of one called [[Teeko]], which he invented in 1945 (version withdrawn), re-invented in 1952 and modified in the 1960s. He was so proud of the game that he named his son [[John Teeko Scarne]]. Teeko quickly spread around the world. Even Orson Welles was reported to have been playing Teeko. But he never made a profit on the game mainly due to water damage in the warehouse which eliminated the entire stock in one day. Today Teeko is virtually unknown.<ref name="Eskin">[https://www.washingtonpost.com/ac2/wp-dyn/A43740-2001Jul10 Eskin, Blake. "A world of games: Cards and gambling authority John Scarne claimed to have invented one of the greatest board games of all time. Was he bluffing?" ''Washington Post'', July 15, 2001, p. W18.]</ref>
Scarne's most famous card trick was appropriately titled "Scarne's Aces". The trick involved taking a spectator's shuffled deck of cards, performing a series of riffle shuffles himself and then cutting to all four aces. Another one of Scarne's most notable card effects was the triple coincidence, in which a spectator and a magician each pick three different playing cards out of two regular decks of opposite colors and it is shown that all of the selections match. Scarne also created a quadruple coincidence, wherein a spectator selects a card and four impossible predictions of their card are made.
Scarne also attempted to discredit [[Edward O. Thorp]]'s blackjack [[card counting]] system.<ref>{{Cite journal |last = Tamburin |first = Henry |title = Legends of Blackjack Honoring the achievements of the game's pioneers |journal = Casino Player |date = July 2002 |url = http://www.casinoplayer.com/archive/0702cp/blackjack_part1.htm |postscript = <!--None--> |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080209122941/http://www.casinoplayer.com/archive/0702cp/blackjack_part1.htm |archivedate = February 9, 2008 |df = mdy-all }}</ref> In his 1966 autobiography ''The Odds Against Me'', he claimed to analyze Thorp's system and concluded that the whole system was loaded with mathematical errors and it was pure fiction dreamed by Thorp. Scarne also went on to attempt to discredit Wilson's famous blackjack point count system. Scarne offered a challenge to blackjack card counters, but Scarne and the prospective participants were never able to agree upon the terms for the challenge.<ref>[http://www.blackjackhero.com/blackjack/strategy/card-counting/history/thorp-scarne/ The History of Card Counting, John Scarne versus Ed Thorp]</ref><ref name="GuideCasinoGambling-challenge">{{cite book | last = Scarne | first = John | title = Scarne's Guide to Casino Gambling | publisher = Simon & Schuster | year = 1978 | location = New York | pages = 122–129 }}</ref>
In ''The Odds Against Me'', Scarne described his own technique for counting down up to four-deck blackjack with the rules generally used in Las Vegas in 1947: Scarne made use of his stacks of chips as a device to help track the contents of the undealt cards.<ref name="OddsAgainstMe-count">{{cite book | last = Scarne | first = John | title = The Odds Against Me | publisher = Simon & Schuster | year = 1966 | location = New York | pages = 366–368 }}</ref> A more complete description of his technique is present in his later book, ''Scarne's Guide to Casino Gambling'', where he also described preventative measures taken by casinos to combat card counting.<ref name="GuideCasinoGambling-count">{{cite book | last = Scarne | first = John | title = Scarne's Guide to Casino Gambling | publisher = Simon & Schuster | year = 1978 | location = New York | pages = 104–106 }}</ref>
==Personal life== Scarne married [[Steffi Scarne|Steffi Storm]] (née [[Steffi Scarne|Norma Kearney]]) in 1955 (and they had [[John Teeko Scarne|John Teeko]] the same year). Scarne died on July 7, 1985 at 82, while living in [[North Bergen, New Jersey]].<ref name=NYTObit/>
==Publications==
*''The Amazing World of John Scarne'' (1956) *''The Odds Against Me'' (1966) *''Scarne on Cards'' (1973) *''Scarne's Encyclopedia of Games'' (1973) * ''The Mafia Conspiracy'' (1976) *''Scarne's Guide to Casino Gambling'' (1978) *''Scarne on Dice'' (1980)
==References== {{reflist}}
*Cook, Joan (July 9, 1985). John Scarne, gambling expert. ''The New York Times'', p. B6. *Eskin, Blake (July 15, 2001). A world of games. ''The Washington Post'' Magazine, p. W18. *Deaths Elsewhere (July 9, 1985). ''The Washington Post'', p. D8.
==External links== *{{IMDb name|0769211}} *[http://streetmagic.info/scarnevideo.html "Expose of Sleight of Hand" Scarne video] *{{Find a Grave|77487303}} *[http://www.cardsanddominoes.com/html/bio_scarne_culbertson_sobel_us.html "Rules for Scarne's invented games Teeko, Skarney, Skarney Gin] {{Authority control}}

{{Coord|24|51|36|N|67|0|36|E|display=title}} {{refimprove|date=June 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=December 2013}} {{Infobox film festival | name = Karachi International Film Festival
کارا فلم فیسٹیول | logo = Kara_Film_Festival_Logo.png | image = | image_size = | caption = | number = | location = [[Karachi]], [[Pakistan]] | language = International | website = {{url|karafilmfest.com}} }} The '''Karachi International Film Festival''', simply known as the '''Kara Film Festival''' (Urdu: '''''کارا فلم فیسٹیول''''' or '''''کارا فلم''''') [http://www.karafilmfest.com/about.htm About us] Official website. was founded in 2001 by the KaraFilm Society, reportedly in response to the declining state of the [[Cinema of Pakistan|Pakistani film industry]]. The film festival was held annually until 2009. The 8th Kara Film Festival was supposed to be held in 2010 but has since been delayed every year due to the socio-economic problems that Karachi was facing. The goal of the festival was to "promote an appreciation of the art and craft of filmmaking among a wide population as well as to encourage creativity and high standards among filmmakers". The Kara Film Festival was founded to celebrate the past galore of [[Cinema of Pakistan|Pakistani cinema]] and help aid in its revival. The festival featured a variety of independent films including [[Documentary film|documentaries]], narrative features and [[Short film|shorts]]. From the 6th festival onwards there was also a family-friendly section of children's [[Animation|animated movies]] There would be a jury who would celebrate emerging and renowned filmmakers by awarding their works. One distinctive feature of the festival was that it would showcase works of art by Pakistani artists. Another feature of the festival was that the opening and closing ceremonies would feature some of the new as well as some of the famed Pakistani musical talent.http://www.karafilmfest.com/KaraFilm2006/currentkara_2006.htm ==History== [[Cineaste One]] a similar institution which substituted KaraFilm by organizing [[COSFF]] and workshops with a greater focus on education, and substituting indie films with student films.Official Website www.cineasteone.org Cineaste One while succeeding KaraFilm festival does not employ anyone involved with it. ==Awards== A jury hands out awards to the films they deem the best at the closing ceremony.http://www.karafilmfest.com/KaraFilm2009/awards09.htm ===Documentary Films=== *Best Documentary ===Short Films=== *Best Live Action Short Film *Best Animated Short Film *Best Telefilm ===Feature Films=== *Best Feature Film *Best Direction *Best Male Actor in a Leading Role *Best Female Actor in a Leading Role *Best Male Actor in a Supporting Role *Best Female Actor in a Supporting Role *Best Screenplay *Best Editing *Best Cinematography *Best Musical Score ===Jury Awards=== *Special Jury Award *Special Jury Award for Acting == See also == * [[Cineaste One Student Film Festival]] * [[Cinema in Karachi]] * [[Cinema of Pakistan]] * [[Festivals in Karachi]] [http://watchmoviesonlinehd.net/ watch Movies online ] ==References== ==External links== *{{Official website|karafilmfest.com}} *[http://www.dawn.com/weekly/images/images2.htm Sixth KaraFilm Festival (7-17 December 2006) - ''Dawn Review''] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20060507000823/http://www.thehotspotonline.com/moviespot/bolly/reviews/k/KaraShorts.htm Kara Shorts - A Review by Bollywood Movie Review] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20061124172241/http://www.nohoartsdistrict.com/tv/Articles/Kara_film_fest.html Ayers Baxter on Kara Film Festival 2004] [[Category:Cinema of Pakistan]] [[Category:Film festivals in Pakistan]] [[Category:Festivals in Karachi]] [[Category:Kariwood]] [[Category:Cinema of Sindh]] [[Category:Short film festivals]] {{film-festival-stub}}

{{Redirect|King of clubs}} {{Redirect|King of spades|the Frederick Manfred novel|King of Spades (novel)}} {{Redirect|King of diamonds|the 1936 film|King of Diamonds (film)|the American television series|King of Diamonds (TV series)}} [[File:King playing cards.jpg|thumb|King cards of all four suits in the [[French playing cards#English pattern|English pattern]]]]
The '''king''' is a [[playing card]] with a picture of a king on it. The king is usually the highest-ranking [[face card]]. In [[French playing cards]] and [[tarot]] decks, the king immediately outranks the [[Queen (playing card)|queen]]. In [[Italian playing cards|Italian]] and [[Spanish playing cards]], the king immediately outranks the [[Knight (playing card)|knight]]. In [[German playing cards|German]] and [[Swiss playing cards]], the king immediately outranks the ''[[Ober (playing card)|Ober]]''. In some games, the king is the highest-ranked card; in others, the [[ace]] is higher. Aces began outranking kings around 1500 with [[Trappola]] being the earliest known game in which the aces were highest in all four suits.<ref name="Parlett">{{cite book|last1=Parlett|first1=David|title=The Oxford Guide to Card Games|date=1990|publisher=Oxford University Press|location=Oxford|page=252}}</ref> In the [[Ace-Ten games|Ace-Ten family]] of games such as [[pinochle]] and [[schnapsen]], both the ace and the 10 rank higher than the king.<ref>McLeod, John. [https://www.pagat.com/aceten/ Ace-Ten Games] at [[pagat.com]]. Retrieved 25 February 2016.</ref>
==History== [[File:Kings-comparison.jpg|thumb|150px|French Rouen pattern on the left, Spanish Toledo pattern on the right]]
The king card is the oldest and most universal court card. It most likely originated in Persian [[Ganjifa|Ganjifeh]] where kings are depicted as seated on thrones and outranking the viceroy cards which are mounted on horses. Playing cards were transmitted to Italy and Spain via the [[Mamluk Sultanate (Cairo)|Mamluks]] and [[Moors]].<ref>{{cite web|author=Tor, Gjerde|url=http://cards.old.no/1500-mamluk/|title=Mamluk cards, ca. 1500|work=old.no}}</ref><ref>Wintle, Simon. [http://www.wopc.co.uk/spain/moorish/index Moorish playing cards] at World of Playing Cards. Retrieved 25 February 2017.</ref> The best preserved and most complete deck of Mamluk cards, the [[Topkapı Palace|Topkapı]] pack, did not display human figures but just listed their rank most likely due to religious prohibition. It is not entirely secure if the Topkapı pack was representative of all Mamluk decks as it was a custom-made luxury item used for display. A fragment of what may be a seated king card was recovered in Egypt which may explain why the poses of court cards in Europe resemble those in Persia and India.<ref name="Dummett">{{cite book|last1=Dummett|first1=Michael|title=The Game of Tarot|date=1980|publisher=Duckworth|location=London|pages=10–64}}</ref>
[[Image:King of Hearts Ruen pattern comparison.jpg|thumb|left|Evolution of the King of Hearts from the Rouennais pattern to the English pattern]]
Seated kings were generally common throughout Europe. During the 15th century, the Spanish started producing standing kings. The French originally used Spanish cards before developing their regional deck patterns. Many Spanish court designs were simply reused when the French invented their own suit-system around 1480.<ref name="Dummett" /> The English imported their cards from [[Rouen]] until the early 17th century when foreign card imports were banned.<ref>[http://i-p-c-s.org/pattern/ps-48.html English pattern] at the [[International Playing-Card Society]]. Retrieved 25 February 2017.</ref> The king of hearts is sometimes called the "suicide king" because he appears to be sticking his sword into his head. This is a result of centuries of bad copying by English card makers where the king's axe head has disappeared.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://whiteknucklecards.com/nsp/rouenpattern.html|title=The Rouen Pattern|work=whiteknucklecards.com}}</ref><ref>Wintle, Simon. [http://www.wopc.co.uk/cards/suicide-king Suicide King] at the World of Playing Cards. Retrieved 25 February 2017.</ref>
Starting in the 15th century, French manufacturers assigned to each of the court cards names taken from history or mythology.<ref>[http://www.snopes.com/history/world/cardking.asp "The Four King Truth"] at the [[Urban Legends Reference Pages]]. Retrieved 25 February 2017.</ref> This practice survives only in the Paris pattern which ousted all its rivals, including the Rouen pattern around 1780.<ref name="Mann">{{cite book|last1=Mann|first1=Sylvia|title=All Cards on the Table|date=1990|publisher=Jonas Verlag|location=Leinfelden|pages=115–124}}</ref><ref>Pollett, Andy. [http://a_pollett.tripod.com/cards21.htm France and Belgium] at Andy's Playing Cards. Retrieved 25 February 2017.</ref> The names for the kings in the Paris pattern (''portrait officiel'') are:<ref>[http://www.i-p-c-s.org/faq/history_14.php Paris and Rouen pattern figures] at the [[International Playing-Card Society]]. Retrieved 25 February 2017.</ref>
{| class="wikitable" | [[File:King of spades fr.svg|center|110px]] || [[File:King of hearts fr.svg|center|110px]] || [[File:King of diamonds fr.svg|center|110px]] || [[File:King of clubs fr.svg|center|110px]] |- | [[David]] || [[Charlemagne|Charles]] || [[Julius Caesar|Caesar]] || [[Alexander the Great|Alexandre]] |} {{clear|left}}
Most French-suited continental European patterns are descended from the Paris pattern but they have dropped the names associated with each card.<ref name="Mann" />
{{clear}}
==Example cards== Kings from [[French playing cards]]: <gallery> Image:Атласная колода король экстра трефы.jpg|King of Clubs (Russian pattern) Image:Атласная колода экстра король бубни.jpg|King of Diamonds (Russian pattern) Image:Атласная колода экстра король черви.jpg|King of Hearts (Russian pattern) Image:Атласная колода экстра король пики.jpg|King of Spades (Russian pattern) Image:Taroky honery.JPG|[[Industrie und Glück]] pattern </gallery>
Kings from [[Italian playing cards]]: <gallery> Image:Bergamo Deck - Wands - King.jpg|King of Clubs (Bergamo pattern) Image:Bergamo Deck - Coins - King.jpg|King of Coins (Bergamo pattern) Image:Bergamo Deck - Cups - King.jpg|King of Cups (Bergamo pattern) Image:Bergamo Deck - Swords - King.jpg|King of Swords (Bergamo pattern) </gallery>
Kings from [[Spanish playing cards]]: <gallery> Image:Aluette card deck - Grimaud - 1858-1890 - King of Clubs.jpg|King of Clubs ([[Aluette]]) Image:Aluette card deck - Grimaud - 1858-1890 - King of Coins.jpg|King of Coins (Aluette) Image:Aluette card deck - Grimaud - 1858-1890 - King of Cups.jpg|King of Cups (Aluette) Image:Aluette card deck - Grimaud - 1858-1890 - King of Swords.jpg|King of Swords (Aluette) Image:TuteFourKings.jpg|Catalan pattern Image:Reyes Tute.jpg|Castilian pattern </gallery>
Kings from [[German playing cards]]: <gallery> Image:Saxonian Deck - Acorns - King.jpg|King of Acorns (Saxon pattern) Image:Saxonian Deck - Bells - King.jpg|King of Bells (Saxon pattern) Image:Saxonian Deck - Hearts - King.jpg|King of Hearts (Saxon pattern) Image:Saxonian Deck - Leaves - King.jpg|King of Leaves (Saxon pattern) </gallery>
==See also== * [[List of poker hand nicknames]]
==References== {{commons category|Kings (playing cards)}} <references/>

{{refimprove|date=January 2015}} {{Supersupportingbox| |image= |caption= |character_name=Kirigi |publisher=[[Marvel Comics]] |debut=''[[Daredevil (Marvel Comics series)|Daredevil]]'' #174 (Sep 1981) |creators=[[Frank Miller (comics)|Frank Miller]] |full_name=Kirigi |alliances=[[The Hand (comics)|The Hand]] |powers=Accomplished martial artist
Weapons master
Superhuman strength and resistance to injury
Healing factor via meditation
Virtual imperviousness to all but devastating wounds |}} '''Kirigi''' is a fictional [[ninja]] [[assassination|assassin]] appearing in [[American comic book]]s published by [[Marvel Comics]]. After being resurrected by [[The Hand (comics)|The Hand]], he works as an operative for the group. He is extremely strong, and is both a weapons master and an accomplished martial artist with an ability to use a form of [[meditation]] that allows him to recover from otherwise-mortal wounds. ==Publication history== Kirigi first appeared in ''[[Daredevil (Marvel Comics series)|Daredevil]]'' #174-176 (September-November 1981), and was created by [[Frank Miller (comics)|Frank Miller]].{{cite web|url=http://www.marvunapp.com/Appendix/kirigi.htm|title=Kirigi (Hand, Elektra foe)|date=1 May 2005|publisher=Appendix to the Handbook of the Marvel Universe|author=Jeff Christiansen|accessdate=22 November 2011}} The character subsequently appears in ''Daredevil'' #187-188 (October-November 1982). ==Fictional character biography== While it is known that the ninjas of ancient [[Japan]] feared Kirigi, little else is known of his history. Kirigi is an opponent of both [[Chaste (Marvel Comics)|The Chaste]], a group commanded by [[Stick (comics)|Stick]], and two of Stick's former pupils, [[Daredevil (Marvel Comics character)|Daredevil]] and [[Elektra (comics)|Elektra Natchios]]. This hatred eventually prompts the Hand to resurrect him in order to destroy Elektra. This plot eventually reaches its climax as Elektra, walking into a trap laid by the Hand, attempts to kill the Hand's Jonin (ninja master) with the assistance of Daredevil. Instead of meeting the Jonin, she meets Kirigi. In response, she stabs him with two sai; however, he merely pulls them out effortlessly. He then dupes her into going for her sai, only to choke her with his rope knife. However, she manages to impale him with her blade, forcing him to break off the fight. A day later, however, he returns to attack Elektra again after recovering from his wounds using meditation and mystic ointments. Once again, a fierce battle ensues. Elektra flees into a semi-rig and smashes into him at a high speed. She then leaps out of the semi-rig before it explodes. In spite of this, Kirigi merely stands back up, though his skin is still engulfed in flames. Finally, Elektra simply decapitates him as he tries to regain his bearings, saying: "God or demon, Kirigi had a neck and that was human enough."''Daredevil'' Vol1 #175-176 (October November 1981){{cite web|url=http://www.theothermurdockpapers.com/2010/03/the-hand-the-life-and-first-death-of-kirigi/|date=14 March 2010|work=The Other Murdock Papers|accessdate=22 November 2011|title=The Hand – The life and (first) death of Kirigi}} Several Hand ninjas soon clash with the Chaste and Daredevil and sacrifice their lives in order to resurrect Kirigi once again, to aid them in their battle against the Chaste and Daredevil. At the moment, Daredevil has temporarily lost control of his enhanced senses and is in an isolation tank with Stick, who is trying to help him regain control of them. The newly revived Kirigi attempts to ambush Stick, but he is no match for the Chaste warriors, who collectively are able to defeat him. Stick then orders Kirigi's body destroyed to prevent him from being resurrected once again.''Daredevil'' Vol1 #187-188 (October November 1982) ==Powers and abilities== Kirigi has a seemingly superhuman resistance to pain and injury. He is capable of lifting at least 1,000 pounds. Both a weapons master and an accomplished martial artist, his various areas of expertise include the use of the Katana, Shuriken, Kyoketsu Shogi (rope knife), and sai. In addition, the use of a form of meditation allows him to recover from otherwise-mortal wounds. As a result, he is virtually impervious to all but devastating wounds. ==In other media== ===Film=== [[File:Kirigi-film.jpg|thumbnail|200px|Kirigi as portrayed in the film ''Elektra'']] * In the 2005 film, ''[[Elektra (2005 film)|Elektra]]'', Kirigi is portrayed by [[Will Yun Lee]].{{cn|date=September 2017}} In addition to being a master swordsman, Kirigi is able to move and attack at superhuman speed. Elektra challenged Kirigi in a final battle on who should get the Treasure, which was a girl named Abby. They fought but Kirigi got the upper hand, beating Elektra around until she realized he killed her mother when she was a child. Kirigi then ran up to her, but Elektra stabbed him in the chest with her sai and threw him into a well, where he disintegrated while falling. ===Video games=== * Kirigi is a boss in the ''[[Daredevil (video game)|Daredevil]]'' video game tie-in to the live-action ''[[Daredevil (film)|Daredevil]]'' film.{{cn|date=September 2017}} In the game, he believes that Daredevil was working for the Kingpin and he has sent the Daredevil to kill him, since the Hand was at war with the Kingpin's gang. Kirigi is seemingly killed by Daredevil after he defeats him. * Kirigi appears as a villain in the [[Massively multiplayer online game|MMO]] ''[[Marvel Heroes (video game)|Marvel Heroes]]''.{{cn|date=September 2017}} ==References== ==External links== * {{Marvunapp|http://www.marvunapp.com/Appendix/kirigi.htm|Kirigi}} {{Daredevil}} [[Category:Comics characters introduced in 1981]] [[Category:Characters created by Frank Miller]] [[Category:Fictional assassins]] [[Category:Fictional Japanese people]] [[Category:Fictional ninja]] [[Category:Fictional swordsmen]] [[Category:Film characters]] [[Category:Marvel Comics demons]] [[Category:Marvel Comics martial artists]] [[Category:Marvel Comics supervillains]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox stage production | name = Lesburlesque | image = Lesburlesque and drag king armwrestle image1.jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = Lesburlesque & Drag Kings | company = | genre = [[Burlesque]] | type = Lesbian Cabaret | premiere = <!-- {{Start date|2010|09|04|df=y}} --> | finalshow = <!-- {{End date|2012|10|13|df=y}} --> | location = [[Manchester]], [[London]], [[United Kingdom]] | creatortitle1 = Founder | creatorname1 = [http://www.pixietruffle.com Pixie Truffle] | creatortitle2 = Co-Founder | creatorname2 = [https://web.archive.org/web/20120726074526/http://kittyliquorofficial.tumblr.com/ Kitty Liquor] | creatortitle3 = Compère | creatorname3 = Rosie Lugosi | creatortitle4 = Original Members | creatorname4 = Isobella Lash, Mona Von Chrome, Twiggy StarLust, Willow Rose, Delilah Cherryblossom | creatortitle9 = Performers | creatorname9 = [[Khandie Khisses]], Diva Hollywood, Marnie Scarlet, Mia Merode, Lady Wildflower, Aurora Galore, Fifi Fatale, TeTe Bang, Chocolat the Extraordinaire, Nanny Dora, Laureat O'Hara, Penny Bizarre, Tottie Spon Sills, Luna Rosa, Glorian Gray, Emerald Ace, Daria D'Beauvoix, Heidi Bang Tidy, Lily La Fox, The Wonderful D, Bella Besame, Ruby Moon Voodoo, Fever Blister, Kitten De Ville | otherlabel1 = Drag King Performers | otherdata1 = Jack The-Lad, Alex Valentine, Juan Kerr, George de Michael, Gent Lee Duzzit, Jack Toffington-Spiffingfellow, Rusty Chrome, Dixie Shuffle | website = http://www.lesburlesque.co.uk }} '''Lesburlesque''' is a British troupe of over thirty [[burlesque]] performers that perform on the [[cabaret]] circuit. They are notable for being the first and only burlesque troupe in the UK that performs [[lesbian]] burlesque. Following on from the success of Los Angeles-based girl band and dance troupe, [[the Pin Up Girls]], Lesburlesque appeared on the burlesque scene in September 2010. They came to wider public attention in 2012 for having performed at a former church and continue to incorporate traditionally lesbian specific [[cabaret]] entertainment, such as [[drag king]]ing to broadening its appeal to the wider cabaret circuit.
==History== Lesburlesque is a British [[burlesque]] and [[dance troupe]], founded by [[lesbian]] cabaret performer Pixie Truffle in 2010. The troupe began as a duet burlesque routine idea, but following favourable responses from established burlesque performers Kitty Liquor, Mona Von Chrome, Isobella Lash and [[March Violets]] vocalist Rosie Garland, aka Rosie Lugosi, Pixie dedicated herself to making Lesburlesque into a fully fledged cabaret group.
Performing at a former place of worship, Platt Chapel (now Unique Manchester), Lesburlesque garnered scathing attention from the British Tabloid press.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/femail/article-2097775/Britains-lesbian-burlesque-troupe-stage--CHURCH.html |title=Britain's first ever lesbian burlesque troupe take to the stage... in a CHURCH | first=Deborah | last=Arthurs |work=The Daily Mail |date=2012-02-07 |accessdate=2012-09-07}}</ref> However the press in Manchester seemed supportive of their efforts to expand the concept of burlesque to the LGBTQ community and to render sapphic art forms such as drag kinging available to a larger audience.<ref name="Mancunian Matters">{{cite news|url=http://mancunianmatters.co.uk/content/10022332-lesbian-burlesque-act-grace-fallowfields-platt-chapel |title=Lesbian burlesque act to grace Fallowfield's Platt Chapel |work=Mancunian Matters |first=Francine | last=Ponticelli |date=2012-02-10 |accessdate=2012-09-07}}</ref><ref name="MEN">{{cite news|url=http://menmedia.co.uk/manchestereveningnews/news/s/1478641_lesbian-burlesque-troupe-to-perform-at-former-church-in-fallowfield |title=Lesbian burlesque troupe to perform at former church in Fallowfield |work=Manchester Evening News |publisher=MEN Media |first=Amy | last=Glendinning |date=2012-02-07 |accessdate=2012-09-07}}</ref>
The troupe continue to use established drag king performers The Dyke Kings and Juan Kerr. Lesburlesque and Pixie continue to spearhead the rise to equality of drag king performance art.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/stage/shortcuts/2012/aug/26/drag-kings-standup-women-comedy |title=How 'drag kings' are taking the standup world by storm |work=The Guardian |first=Nadeem | last=Akhtar |date=2012-08-26 |accessdate=2012-09-07}}</ref> In an exchange between Pixie and actress and feminist writer Rhona Foulis, Pixie claims it is "...her personal mission to bring lesbian performances to a mainstream audience, in exactly the same way as drag queens have been accepted."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.progressivewomen.org.uk/neo-burlesque-neo-blog/ |title=Neo-burlesque, neo-blog |publisher=Progressive Women |first=Rhona |last=Foulis|date=2011-12-22 |accessdate=2012-09-08}}</ref>
==Associations== The troupe continues to be associated with the Lesbian Community Project,<ref name="Mancunian Matters" /><ref name="MEN" /> a charitable organisation that helps to put lesbians in touch with each other across Manchester and to provide counselling and fun activities.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lesbiancommunityproject.co.uk/ |title=Lesbian Community Project |publisher=Lesbian Community Project |date= |accessdate=2012-09-10}}</ref>
On their first anniversary Pixie Truffle formed a one off partnership with Bella Besame, the founder and promoter of The Slippery Belle Presents...BURLESQUE! revue in Manchester.
On their second anniversary Pixie announced a partnership with The Singapore Burlesque Club,<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.sukkisingapora.com/images/Sukki-Singapora-makes-it-into-My-Paper-Newspaper-Singapore_xlarge.jpg |title=Bring on the Burlesque! |work=MyPaper |publisher=[http://www.mypaper.sg/ MyPaper] |first=Sue-Anne |last=Lim |date=2011-11-29 |accessdate=2012-09-10 }}{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> a well-known Burlesque revue in [[Singapore]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://chwennyland.com/2011/11/10/i-found-a-burlesque-star-in-my-own-backyard/ |title=I Found A Burlesque Star In My Own Backyard |publisher=Chwenny Wordpress Blog |first=Sue-Anne| last=Lim|date=2011-11-10 |accessdate=2012-09-08}}</ref> Singapore is a country with stringent controls on public nudity<ref>{{cite news|url=http://statutes.agc.gov.sg/aol/search/display/view.w3p;ident=cca997e7-498a-4778-bc6a-70f965161b83;page=0;query=DocId%3Aca5b9bd4-5b2e-4b42-9349-a5aaf258d9a4%20%20Status%3Ainforce%20Depth%3A0;rec=0#pr27A-he-. |title=MISCELLANEOUS OFFENCES (PUBLIC ORDER AND NUISANCE) ACT (CHAPTER 184) |work=The Singapore Attorney General's Chamber|accessdate=2012-09-08}}</ref> and the Burlesque Club's stance, and association with a Lesbian Burlesque troupe, would at the very least be at odds with the state of women's rights and gay rights in its native Singapore.
==Performances== * Grrrl Meets Boi, [http://www.lesbiancommunityproject.co.uk/ The Lesbian Community Project], Manchester (February 26, 2011) * The Slippery Belle Presents...Lesburlesque! (March 2, 2012) * Lesburlesque Presents Sapphic Pride (August 25, 2012) * Lesburlesque Presents... In Association with The Singapore Burlesque Club ....INTERNATIONAL ENCHANTRESS NIGHT with Burlesque Legend Kitten De Ville (October 13, 2012)
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== # {{Official website|http://www.lesburlesque.co.uk/}}

{{unreferenced|date=May 2018}} '''List of Scottish country dances''' is a list of [[Scotland|Scottish]] [[Scottish country dance|country dances]]. There are well over 15000 documented Scottish country dances so only very frequently danced or notable ones are listed here.
''Dances below are marked with the music and dance styles used: R8×32 3C/4 means a Reel of 32 bars repeated 8 times for 3 couples in a set of 4 couples in a longwise set. The letters for the music styles are: R [[Reel (dance)|reel]]; J [[jig]]; P [[polka]]; S [[strathspey (dance)|strathspey]]; W [[waltz]]''
{{dynamic_list}}
*[[Anniversary Reel]] – R4×32 4C set – Sheila Muir 1987 *[[Maggieknockater|The Bees of Maggieknockater]] – J4×32 4C set – John Drewry 1975 *[[The Belle of Bon Accord]] – S4×32 4C set – John Drewry 1981 *[[Blooms of Bon Accord]] – R4×32 4C set – John Drewry 1971 *[[Bratach Bana]] – J8x32 3C/4 – John Drewry 1964 *[[Clutha (dance)|Clutha]] – R4×48 Square set – unknown 1890 *[[Dashing White Sergeant]] – 32 bar reel 3 facing 3 round the room – unknown *[[The De'il Amang the Tailors (dance)|The De'il Amang the Tailors]] – R8×32 3C/4 – unknown *[[The Dream Catcher (dance)|The Dream Catcher]] – S96 Square set – Eileen Orr *[[The Duke and Duchess of Edinburgh]] – R8×40 3C/4 – Allie Anderson & Florence Lesslie *[[The Duke of Atholl's Reel]] – J8×32 3C/4 – Skillern 1776 *[[Duke of Perth (reel)|The Duke of Perth]] – R8x32 3C/4 – unknown 1827 *[[The Earl of Mansfield]] – R4x48 4C – John Drewry 1980 *[[The Eightsome reel]] – R40+8x48+40 Square set – unknown 1870 *[[Fergus McIver]] (a.k.a. Waverley) – J8x48 3C/4 – Button and Whittaker 1812 *[[Flowers of Edinburgh]] – R8x32 3C/4 Hornpipe – unknown *[[The Frisky]] – J8x32 3C/4 – Robert Bremner *[[Gay Gordons (dance)|Gay Gordons]] – 16 bar round the room march – unknown *[[Hamilton House (dance)|Hamilton House]] – J8x32 3C/4 – William Campbell 1789 *[[Hooper's Jig]] – J8x32 3C/4 – unknown *[[Ian Powrie]]'s [[Farewell to Auchterarder]] – J128 Square set – Bill Hamilton *[[Joie de Vivre (dance)|Joie de Vivre]] – J8x32 3C/4 – Irene van Maarseveen *[[Roger de Coverley|The Haymakers]] (a.k.a. Sir Roger de Coverley) – 48 bar 9/8 jig – unknown *[[Inverneill House]] – R8x32 3C/4 – John Drewry 1986 *[[The Irish Rover]] – R8×32 3C/4 – James B Cosh *[[Milne, J.B.|J.B. Milne]] – R8x32 3C/4 – Hugh Foss 1954 *[[Jennifer's Jig]] – J8×32 3C/4 – John Drewry 1968 *[[MacDonald of the Isles]] – S3×32 3C – Derek Haynes *[[The Machine without horses]] – J8x32 3C/4 – Rutherford 1772 *[[Mairi's Wedding]] – R8x40 3C/4 – James B. Cosh 1959 (See also [[Wedding music#Scottish|Wedding music]]) *[[Major Ian Stewart]] – J8x32 3C/4 – John Drewry 1986 *[[Maxwell's Rant]] – R8x32 3C/4 – Rutherford 1752 *[[Miss Johnstone of Ardrossan]] – R5x32 5C – Roy Goldring 2000 *[[Mrs Stewart's Jig]] – J8x32 3C/4 – Frans Ligtmans 1986 *[[The Skating Minister|The Minister on the Loch]] – S3×32 3C – Roy Goldring *[[The Montgomeries’ Rant]] – R8x32 3C/4 – Castle Menzies 1749 *[[Monymusk (dance)|Monymusk]] – S8x32 3C/4 – Preston 1786 *[[Napier's Index]] – J8x40 3C/4 – Brian Charlton 2001 *[[Neidpath Castle]] – S3×32 3C – Derek Haynes *[[Pelorus Jack]] – J8×32 3C/4 – Barry Skelton 1993 *[[Petronella]] – R8x32 2C/4 – unknown 1808 *[[Postie’s Jig]] – J4x32 4C – Roy Clowes *[[Quarries' Jig]] – J8x32 3C/4 – Kent W Smith *[[The Reel of the Royal Scots]] – R8×32 3C/4 – Roy Goldring 1983 *[[The Reel of the 51st Division]] – R8x32 3C/4 – James Edward McCartney Atkinson 1940 *[[Rest and Be Thankful]] – R8x32 3C/4 – unknown *[[The Robertson Rant]] – S80 Square – Mrs Douglas Winchester 1949 *[[The Sailor (dance)|The Sailor]] – R8x32 3C/4 – unknown *[[Scottish Reform]] – J8x32 2C/4 – unknown *[[Shiftin’ Bobbins]] – R8x32 3C/4 – Roy Clowes *[[Inverness Country Dance|Speed the Plough]] (Inverness Country Dance) – R8x32 3C/4 – unknown *[[Strip the willow|Strip the Willow]] – 40 or 56 bar jig in either 6/8 or 9/8 time (in 9/8 it is also known as "Drops of Brandy") – unknown *[[Sugar Candie]] – S8×32 3C/4 – unknown *[[Swiss Lassie]] – R8×32 3C/4 – Rosi Betschi *[[A Trip to Bavaria]] – R4x32 4C – James MacGregor-Brown *[[Up in {{External links|date=June 2016}} The following is a list of [[radio]] stations in [[Belgium]].
== Public broadcasters == Belgium has three public broadcasters, one for each national language. * The [[Vlaamse Radio- en Televisieomroeporganisatie]] ('''VRT''') for the Dutch-speaking [[Flemish Community]] ([[Flanders]] and [[Brussels]]) * The [[Radio Télévision Belge Francophone]] ('''RTBF''') for the [[French Community of Belgium]] ([[Wallonia]] and [[Brussels]]) * The [[Belgischer Rundfunk]] ('''BRF''') for the [[German-speaking Community of Belgium]] ([[East Cantons]] and [[Brussels]])
== List of FM radio services by community == {{Expand list|date=February 2014}}The following is a list of FM radio stations broadcasting in Belgium. There is also [[Dab+|DAB+]] coverage in many parts of Belgium, with most of the DAB+ stations being available on FM as well.
=== The Flemish Community === {{See|Radio in the Flemish Community}}
=== The French Community === {{col-begin}} {{col-4}}
====Public ([[Radio Télévision Belge Francophone|RTBF]])==== * [[La Première]] * [[VivaCité]] ** ''VivaBruxelles'' <small>(local programs in [[Brussels]])</small> ** ''VivaCité'' <small>(local programs in [[Liège]], [[Wavre]], [[Namur (city)|Namur]], [[Mons]], [[Luxembourg (Belgium)|Luxembourg]] and [[Charleroi]])</small> * [[Classic 21]] * [[Pure FM]] * [[Musiq'3]]{{col-4}}
====Nationwide==== * [[Bel RTL]] * [[Radio Contact (Belgium)|Radio Contact]] * [[Fun Radio (Belgium)|Fun Radio]] * [[Nostalgie Wallonie]] * [[NRJ (Belgium)|NRJ]] * Twizz Radio
{{col-4}}
====Regional stations==== * Antipode <small>([[Walloon Brabant]])</small> * Maximum FM <small>([[Liège]])</small> * Must FM <small>([[Luxembourg (Belgium)|Luxembourg]], [[Namur (province)|Namur]])</small> * Radio KIF <small>([[Brussels]])</small> * Sud Radio <small>([[Hainaut (province)|Hainaut]])</small> * Vibration FM <small>([[Brussels]])</small>
{{col-4}}
====Local stations==== * Fréquence Eghezée ([[Eghezée]], Province de Namur) * Radio Quartz ([[Sombreffe]], Province de Namur) * 48FM ([[Liège]]) * Ultrason ([[Nivelles]]) * YouFM ([[Mons]]) * Hit Radio ([[Namur (city)|Namur]]) * Warm ([[Liège (city)|Liège]])
{{col-end}}
=== The German Community === ====Public ([[Belgischer Rundfunk|BRF]])==== * [[BRF 1]] * [[BRF 2]] * [[BRF-DLF]] ([[Brussels]])
====Regional stations==== * [[100.5 Das Hitradio]] ([[East Cantons]]) * [[Radio Contact]] ([[East Cantons]]) * [[Fantasy Dance FM]] ([[East Cantons]]) * [[Radio 700]] ([[East Cantons]]) * [[Radio Sunshine]] ([[East Cantons]])
== Other languages ==
=== English language === * [[American Forces Network#SHAPE (Belgium)|AFN Benelux]] ([http://www.afneurope.net/Stations/Benelux.aspx] - ([[Everberg]]) and nearby : 101.7 MHz FM and Online - ([[Mons]]) : 104.2 MHz FM * [[BBC World Service]] ([http://bbc.com/worldserviceradio]) - ([[Brussels]]) region and Flanders : DAB+ Block 11A - 216.928 MHz and Online

=== Arabic language === * AraBel FM ([http://www.arabel.fm/]) - Brussels and surroundings : 106.8 MHz FM and Online (70% French and 30% Arabic)
=== Spanish language === * Radio Alma ([http://www.radioalma.be/]) - Brussels and surroundings : 101.9 MHz FM and Online (Mixture of French and Mediterranean languages : Spanish, Italian, Greek, Portuguese)
=== Italian language === * Radio Italia ([http://www.radioitaliacharleroi.com/]) - Charleroi : 105.2 MHZ FM and Online

{{for|the 1995 film|Man of the House (1995 film)}} {{Infobox film | name = Man of the House | image = Man of the housemposter.jpg | caption = Theatrical release poster | director = [[Stephen Herek]] | producer = {{ubl|[[Steven Reuther]]|Todd Garner|Allyn Stewart}} | screenplay = {{ubl|Robert Ramsey|Matthew Stone|John J. McLaughlin}} | story = {{ubl|John J. McLaughlin|Scott Lobdell}} | starring = {{plainlist| * [[Tommy Lee Jones]] * [[Anne Archer]] * [[Brian Van Holt]] * [[Christina Milian]] * [[Paula Garcés]] * [[Monica Keena]] * [[R. Lee Ermey]] }} | music = [[David Newman (composer)|David Newman]] | cinematography = [[Peter Menzies Jr.]] | editing ={{ubl|[[Chris Lebenzon]]|Joel Negron}} | studio = [[Revolution Studios]] | distributor = [[Columbia Pictures]] | released = {{Film date|2005|02|25}} | runtime = 100 minutes | country = United States | language = English | budget = $40 million<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0331933/business|title=Business at imdb.com}}</ref> | gross = $21.6 million<ref name="BOM">{{cite web|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=manofthehouse05.htm|title=Man of the House (2005)|work=[[Box Office Mojo]]|accessdate=January 5, 2018}}</ref> }} '''''Man of the House''''' is a 2005 American [[crime film|crime]] [[comedy film]] directed by [[Stephen Herek]] and starring [[Tommy Lee Jones]]. The plot revolves around Lt. Roland Sharp, a lonesome [[Texas Ranger Division|Texas Ranger]] who goes undercover as an assistant coach to protect a group of college cheerleaders who have witnessed a murder. Much of the film was shot in [[Austin, Texas]] on the [[University of Texas at Austin|University of Texas]] campus.
[[Governor of Texas|Texas Governor]] [[Rick Perry]] has a cameo appearance in the film as himself. Released on February 25, 2005, the film received negative reviews, and grossed just $21 million against a budget of $40 million.
== Plot == At the beginning of the film, two lonesome [[Texas Ranger Division|Texas Rangers]], Roland Sharp ([[Tommy Lee Jones]]) and Maggie Swanson ([[Liz Vassey]]), are going to a church in order to question Percy Stevens ([[Cedric the Entertainer]]) about the whereabouts of his former prison roommate, Morgan Ball, who they want to testify against organized crime boss John Cortland. Percy is indignant, telling Sharp and Swanson that he is a "man of God" and has not spoken with Ball in years. However, Percy's cellphone rings, displaying Ball's name.
Sharp and Swanson track down Ball to the warehouse, where Ball gives Sharp a key in an attempt to buy him off. Instead, Sharp takes the key and forces Ball outside, where FBI agent Eddie Zane ([[Brian Van Holt]]) is waiting. As they talk, a sniper begins shooting, wounding Swanson and giving Ball a chance to escape. It is revealed the sniper is after Ball, and a group of cheerleaders from the [[University of Texas at Austin]] witness his murder. Agent Zane is found shot in the arm next to Ball's body and claims he didn't see the sniper.
Anne ([[Christina Milian]]), Teresa ([[Paula Garcés]]), Evie ([[Monica Keena]]), Heather ([[Vanessa Ferlito]]) and Barb ([[Kelli Garner]]) are taken to the police station, where they all have conflicting descriptions of the shooter. Sharp is given the task of protecting the girls at all times, because their fathers are worried about them. The information is relayed to him by the [[Governor of Texas]] ([[Rick Perry]]).
It is revealed that Sharp is divorced and has a daughter, Emma ([[Shannon Marie Woodward]]) who is in high school and doesn't feel as though her father had ever been around. John Cortland is been exonerated from all charges pressed against him due to a lack of evidence. FBI Agent Zane is revealed to be working with Cortland, having killed Ball and shot himself in the arm.
Cortland scolds Zane for letting some "loose ends" escape, and Zane begins searching for Sharp and the cheerleaders; he also kills the sniper he hired. With Swanson in the hospital recovering from her near-fatal wound, Sharp and two additional rangers must now pick the girls up from school and secure their sorority house. Sharp moves in with the girls and the two young men with him move into the fraternity house across the street, where they end up busting a drug deal.
Sharp sets some ground rules, including no cell phones. He also tells them to "cover up in his presence" (referring to the girls' revealing clothes). When they fail to comply, he orders a massive industrial air conditioner, forcing them to dress warmly. Sharp is posing as a cheerleading coach specializing in conditioning, and at a [[Texas Longhorns football|Longhorns]] football game he tackles an opposing team's mascot when the mascot approaches the girls with a gun, later revealed to be a water gun. Other humorous mishaps occur, but Sharp's relationship with the girls begins to strengthen; Barb even begins to develop a crush on him.
However, Sharp finds himself attracted to Barb's English teacher Molly ([[Anne Archer]]) who calls him into her office to complain about Barb's [[plagiarism]]. Later he invites her over for dinner, which the girls coach him through using an earpiece and tiny video screen. After they fall asleep, he turns it off and woos Molly himself. He admits to the girls about his last failed marriage and the way he feels about his estranged daughter. This interests Evie, who has a 4.0 [[GPA]] and wants to write a paper on Emma. She uses the house's "emergency phone" to call her, revealing Sharp's location to Zane, who had contacted Emma.
Sharp takes the girls to a "spirit rally", where he is forced to give a speech about cheerleading. He becomes more and more impassioned, proving to the girls he finally "gets it". The night is ruined, however, when Sharp realizes in the nick of time that somebody put a bomb under their van, and Teresa (who was convinced that nobody was after them) is almost killed when her seatbelt gets stuck. Sharp saves her, and she admits that maybe someone is trying to kill them.
Evie tells Sharp she contacted Emma, and when Sharp calls his daughter he learns that Zane has her. He tells Sharp to take the key Ball gave him to open a lockbox, both of them unaware the cheerleaders are listening in. The next day Sharp gets the money out of the lockbox and drives to where Zane instructs him. Zane gives Sharp instructions over a cell phone, telling him he will shoot Emma if Sharp disobeys. After Sharp handcuffs himself to the steering wheel, Zane thanks him and tells him he's a "good parent." Zane takes off with the money, Sharp's keys and phone, and Emma.
Zane and Emma get on a bus, but as it pulls away Sharp sees Barb in the back. As he wonders what is going on, Heather gets in the car with him and picks his handcuffs. They take off after the bus in a stolen [[Volkswagen Beetle]]. On the bus, Teresa pretends to go into labor and Evie demands the bus be stopped. She attempts to steal the bag with the money, but Zane pulls a gun and Evie runs away from the bus. Zane forces all of the other passengers and the driver out, taking over driving the bus himself.
Emma is rescued by the cheerleaders, but Zane attempts to drive to Mexico with the bag to hide. Sharp shoots a wheel, causing the bus to flip over 90 degrees. Zane gets out the bus, his face injured after he hits the bus's ceiling. The [[Mexico-United States border]] closes and the border officers draw guns on him, forcing him to surrender. Sharp shoots the gun out of Zane's hand, and handcuffs him with the very same cuffs Heather freed him from earlier. He and Emma are reunited. At the end of the film, Cortland is arrested and taken back to court, Sharp and Molly are married, and Emma and the cheerleaders are part of the wedding.
== Cast == * [[Tommy Lee Jones]] as Roland Sharp * [[Cedric the Entertainer]] as Percy Stevens * [[Christina Milian]] as Anne * [[Monica Keena]] as Evie * [[Kelli Garner]] as Barb * [[Vanessa Ferlito]] as Heather * [[Paula Garcés]] as Teresa * [[Anne Archer]] as Professor Molly McCarthy * [[Brian Van Holt]] as Eddie Zane * [[Shea Whigham]] as Ranger Holt * Terrence Parks as Ranger Riggs * [[R. Lee Ermey]] as Captain Nichols * [[Paget Brewster]] as Binky * [[Shannon Marie Woodward]] as Emma Sharp * [[Liz Vassey]] as Maggie Swanson * [[Rick Perry]] as himself
== Reception ==
=== Critical reaction === On [[Rotten Tomatoes]], the film has an approval rating of 9% based on 64 reviews, with an average rating of 3.4/10. The site's critical consensus reads, "A high-concept movie that plays out like a mediocre TV sitcom."<ref>{{cite web |title = Man of the House (2005) |url = https://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/man_of_the_house/ |work = [[Rotten Tomatoes]]}}</ref> On [[Metacritic]], the film has a score of 35 out of 100 based on 20 critics, indicating "generally unfavorable reviews".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.metacritic.com/movie/man-of-the-house|title=Man of the House Reviews|work=[[Metacritic]]}}</ref> Audiences polled by [[CinemaScore]] gave the film an average grade of "B–" on an A+ to F scale.<ref name="CinemaScore">{{cite web|url=https://m.cinemascore.com |title=CinemaScore |work=cinemascore.com}}</ref>
[[James Berardinelli]] of ''[[ReelViews]]'' panned the film, rating it one star out of four and writing: "The movie is an "action comedy" in name only - there's nothing in ''Man of the House'' that could be considered funny or exciting." He also said the movie "manages to neuter Cedric the Entertainer's capacity for humor" since "not even he is able to deliver a legitimate laugh" and that Tommy Lee Jones "comes across as taciturn and unlikable."<ref>{{cite web|first=James|last=Berardinelli|url=http://preview.reelviews.net/movies/m/man_house.html |title= Man of the House |publisher=[[ReelViews]] |date= |accessdate=}}</ref>
[[Stephen Hunter]] of the ''[[Washington Post]]'' called the film "a one-screen multiplex" with "a lot of small movies bouncing around inside it, but there's no big movie on the outside." Hunter felt that by the end the "many personalities" of the film have "grown tiresome". Nonetheless, he complimented Tommy Lee Jones' "deadpan" portrayal, saying "Whenever Herek doesn't know what to do -- and that's frequently -- he cuts to Jones, radiating world-weariness with the aplomb of Fred Astaire, and it's always funny."<ref>{{cite web|first=Stephen|last=Hunter|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2005/02/26/AR2005062900968.html |title= Tommy Lee Jones: Lone Star in a Big 'House' |publisher=[[Washington Post]] |date= |accessdate=}}</ref>
Dana Stevens of the ''[[New York Times]]'' wrote: "Nearly every one of the film's emotional scenes is too predictable to hit its mark, but Mr. Jones's dry delivery has its moments." However, Stevens found Cedric the Entertainer to be disappointing, stating that he "fails for once to live up to his name".<ref>{{cite web|first=Dana|last=Stevens|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2005/02/26/movies/texas-ranger-assigned-to-sorority-house.html |title= Texas Ranger Assigned To Sorority House |publisher=[[New York Times]] |date= |accessdate=}}</ref>
=== Box office === In its opening weekend, the film grossed $8,917,251 in 2,422 theaters in the United States and Canada, ranking #5 at the box office and averaging $3,681 per theater. The film closed on April 7, 2005, with a North American domestic gross of $19,699,706 and an international gross of $1,877,918 for a worldwide gross of $21,577,624. The film was released in the [[United Kingdom]] on April 8, 2005, and opened on #14.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.25thframe.co.uk/charts/chart.php?chart=20050408|title=UK Weekend Box Office 8th April 2005 - 10th April 2005|publisher=www.25thframe.co.uk|accessdate=21 June 2018}}</ref>
