=== Initial claim === {{tweet|text=Terrible! Just found out that Obama had my "wires tapped" in Trump Tower just before the victory. Nothing found. This is McCarthyism!|name=Donald J. Trump|username=realDonaldTrump|date=4 Mar 2017|id=837989835818287106|reference={{efn|name=original-tweets}}}}
In a succession of tweets on March 4,{{efn|name=original-tweets|The original tweets, in chronological order, are: * {{Cite tweet|user=realDonaldTrump|number=837989835818287106|title=Terrible! Just found out that Obama had my "wires tapped" in Trump Tower just before the victory. Nothing found. This is McCarthyism!|date=March 4, 2017|access-date=March 21, 2017}} * {{Cite tweet|user=realDonaldTrump|number=837993273679560704|title=Is it legal for a sitting President to be "wire tapping" a race for president prior to an election? Turned down by court earlier. A NEW LOW!|date=March 4, 2017|access-date=March 21, 2017}} * {{Cite tweet|user=realDonaldTrump|number=837994257566863360|title=I'd bet a good lawyer could make a great case out of the fact that President Obama was tapping my phones in October, just prior to Election!|date=March 4, 2017|access-date=March 21, 2017}} * {{Cite tweet|user=realDonaldTrump|number=837996746236182529|title=How low has President Obama gone to tapp my phones during the very sacred election process. This is Nixon/Watergate. Bad (or sick) guy!"|date=March 4, 2017|access-date=March 21, 2017}} }} President [[Donald Trump]] stated he had "just found out" that former president [[Barack Obama]] had wiretapped his phones at [[Trump Tower]] during the last month of the [[United States presidential election, 2016|2016 election]].<ref name="WaPost no evidence">{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/post-politics/wp/2017/03/04/trump-accuses-obama-of-nixonwatergate-plot-to-wire-tap-trump-tower/ |title=Trump, citing no evidence, accuses Obama of 'Nixon/Watergate' plot to wiretap Trump Tower|date=March 4, 2017|work=The Washington Post|author1=Philip Rucker|author2=Ellen Nakashima|author3=Robert Costa|accessdate=March 8, 2017}}</ref> He did not say where he had obtained the information and offered no evidence to support it.<ref name="Politifact no evidence">{{Cite journal |title=Why the White House defense of Trump wiretap accusation is misleading |author=Allison Graves |date=March 5, 2017 |journal=Politifact |url=http://www.politifact.com/truth-o-meter/statements/2017/mar/05/sarah-huckabee-sanders/why-white-houses-defense-trump-accusing-obama-wire/ }}</ref> Trump compared the alleged intrusion to [[McCarthyism]] and [[Watergate]]. Anonymous White House officials told ''[[The Washington Post]]'' that Trump did not appear to coordinate his comments with other White House officials.<ref name="WaPost no evidence" />
=== Followup === The White House claimed that reports "from BBC, ''Heat Street'', ''New York Times'', Fox News, among others" established the president's wiretapping allegation, providing links of these to ''The Washington Post''.<ref name="British Lawmaker" />
In a statement issued through press secretary [[Sean Spicer]] on March 5, Trump asked congressional intelligence committees to "determine whether executive branch investigative powers were abused in 2016" as part of their investigation into [[Russian interference in the 2016 United States elections|Russian interference in the election]].<ref name="Comey refute">{{cite news|author1=Michael S. Schmidt|author2=Michael D. Shear|title=Trump, citing no evidence, accuses Obama of 'Nixon/Watergate' plot to wiretap Trump Tower|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/03/05/us/politics/trump-seeks-inquiry-into-allegations-that-obama-tapped-his-phones.html |accessdate=March 8, 2017|work=The New York Times|date=March 5, 2017}}</ref> In response, Representative [[Devin Nunes]], who chairs the [[United States House Permanent Select Committee on Intelligence|House Intelligence Committee]], stated that the committee "will make inquiries into whether the government was conducting surveillance activities on any political party's campaign officials or surrogates."<ref name="PBS investigate">{{cite news|title=Congress to investigate Trump's wiretapping claim|url=https://www.pbs.org/newshour/rundown/congress-investigate-trumps-wiretapping-claim/|work=PBS Newshour|date=March 6, 2017}}</ref> Senator [[Lindsey Graham]] stated his willingness to use subpoena powers to find out whether Trump was investigated and what the cause for such an investigation was, if it did occur.<ref name="Cnn graham">{{cite news|author=Manu Raju|title=Graham ready to subpoena for Trump wiretap information|url=http://www.cnn.com/2017/03/08/politics/graham-wiretap-russia-subpoena/index.html|work=CNN|date=March 9, 2017}}</ref> On March 15, Nunes reported that the House Intelligence Committee had not found any evidence supporting the wiretapping claim.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/obama-wiretapped-trump-tower-evidence-intelligence-committee-2017-3|title='Clearly the president is wrong': House intel committee says it's seen 'no evidence' that Obama wiretapped Trump Tower|last=Bertrand|first=Natasha|date=March 15, 2017|work=Business Insider|access-date=March 15, 2017|language=en}}</ref>
White House officials gave discordant responses to initial media inquiries about Trump's accusations. Spicer banned cameras in the briefing room at a press conference the following day. White House counselor [[Kellyanne Conway]] told [[Fox News]]'s ''[[Fox & Friends]]'' that the president had "information and intelligence that the rest of us do not," although Spicer later said Conway was not qualified to make that claim.<ref name="Clapper Meet the Press">{{cite news|author1=Ashley Parker|author2=Jenna Johnson|title=White House aides struggle to defend Trump wiretap claims|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/white-house-aides-contort-themselves-trying-to-defend-trump-wiretap-claims/2017/03/06/fef6e368-02aa-11e7-ad5b-d22680e18d10_story.html|accessdate=March 8, 2017|work=The Washington Post|date=March 6, 2017}}</ref>
== Extension of claim == During an interview on March 12, Conway told [[The Record (Bergen County)|''The Record'']]'s [[Mike Kelly (journalist)|Mike Kelly]] that the surveillance could have potentially used hacked electronic devices: "You can surveil someone through their phones, certainly through their television sets — any number of ways." She also suggested that Trump could have been monitored with "microwaves that turn into cameras."<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.northjersey.com/story/news/columnists/mike-kelly/2017/03/12/mike-kelly-conway-suggests-even-wider-surveillance-trump-campaign/99060910/|title=Kellyanne Conway alludes to even wider surveillance of Trump campaign|work=North Jersey|access-date=March 13, 2017|language=en}}</ref> Conway later retracted the claim, stating that "I'm not [[Inspector Gadget#Inspector Gadget|Inspector Gadget]], I don't believe that people are using the microwave to spy on the Trump campaign."<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/kellyanne-conway-dont-believe-microwaves-used-spy-trump-campaign-surveillance-inspector-gadget-2017-3|title='I'm not Inspector Gadget': Kellyanne Conway refutes claims that she suggested Trump's team may have been spied on with microwaves|work=Business Insider|access-date=March 14, 2017|language=en}}</ref>
At a March 13 press briefing, Spicer claimed that Trump was referring to general surveillance rather than direct wiretapping.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Politics/spicer-trump-talking-general-surveillance-wiretapping-tweets/story?id=46101282|title=Trump was talking about general surveillance in wiretapping claims, Spicer says|last=Keneally|first=Meghan|date=March 13, 2017|publisher=ABC News|accessdate=March 14, 2017}}</ref> Spicer also said that the White House believed that the [[Obama administration]] was responsible for the surveillance, not Obama himself, said Trump's tweet which specifically named the former president.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/sean-spicer-trump-doesnt-really-think-obama-ordered-wiretap-2017-3|title=Sean Spicer says Trump 'doesn't really think' Obama 'personally' wiretapped Trump|work=Business Insider|accessdate=March 14, 2017}}</ref>
In a March 15 interview with [[Tucker Carlson]] on Fox News, Trump supported his claims of wiretapping by citing a March 3 interview with [[Paul Ryan]] on an episode of ''[[Special Report (Fox News program)|Special Report with Bret Baier]]'' on Fox News and the January 19 ''New York Times'' article.<ref name=":1" /> While ''The New York Times'' article<ref name="Trump Russia Investigation" /> mentioned "wiretapping" and reported that the FBI was "examining intercepted communications and financial transactions", it stipulated neither the targeting of American citizens for surveillance, nor any involvement in such surveillance by the Obama administration. Trump's March 15 assertion that the ''Times''' article supported his allegations about wiretapping was deemed "false" by [[PolitiFact]].<ref name="HtStreetcopypasta" /><ref name=":1">{{cite web|url=https://www.usnews.com/news/national-news/articles/2017-03-16/donald-trump-tells-tucker-carlson-source-of-wiretapping-claim-was-new-york-times-and-fox-news|title=Trump Says NYT, Fox News Sources for Wiretapping Claims|website=U.S. News & World Report|publisher=US News|last1=Levy|first1=Gabrielle|accessdate=March 17, 2017}}</ref> On [[Special Report (Fox News program)|''Special Report'']] Brett Baier alleged that the FBI got a FISA warrant in October to "start a wiretap at Trump Tower with some computer and Russian banks and it doesn't show up anything [referring to the Trump campaign's alleged links to [[Russian interference in the 2016 United States elections|Russian election meddling]]], by reporting," and asked Ryan: "Have you heard that?" Ryan responded: "Well, again, like I said, none of us in Congress or anybody I know in Congress has been presented with anything to the contrary of what you just said." However, there may have been a misunderstanding between Baier and Ryan throughout the interview, with Baier asking about undue surveillance of the Trump campaign, and Ryan responding that intelligence gathering had produced no evidence of collusion between Russia and Trump. Ryan stated, in response to a question about Trump's March 15 comments, that he had been unaware of any wiretapping allegations prior to his interview with Baier, and that "the intelligence committees ... have determined ... that no such wiretap existed."<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/trump-wiretap-paul-ryan-bret-baier-fox-news-2017-3|title=Trump suggests little-noticed interview between Fox News host and Paul Ryan helped fuel his explosive wiretap claims|work=Business Insider|access-date=March 21, 2017|language=en}}</ref>
=== Allegation of British involvement === {{Quote box | quote = If the telephone rang in GCHQ from the White House, that in itself would be unheard of. The director [GCHQ's chief] would then ring his US counterpart, the director of the NSA—there's a hotline on his desk—to ask if it was a hoax. The next person he would ring would be the [UK] foreign secretary to say we've had this amazing request. Nothing would happen without a warrant from the top of government and that would just never be granted in these circumstances. | author =-- David Omand (former GCHQ director) | source =''Financial Times''<ref name=":5" /> | quoted = 1 | align = right | width = 300px }}
During a March 14 ''Fox & Friends'' interview, [[Andrew Napolitano]] said that "Three intelligence sources have informed Fox News that President Obama went outside the chain of command," using the British [[Government Communications Headquarters]] (GCHQ) to implement surveillance to avoid leaving "American fingerprints."<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://insider.foxnews.com/2017/03/14/judge-napolitano-why-there-may-never-be-proof-even-if-obama-spied-trump|title=Judge Nap: Obama 'Went Outside Chain of Command,' Used British Spy Agency to Surveil Trump|last=|first=|date=March 14, 2017|publisher=Fox News|access-date=March 14, 2017}}</ref> Napolitano accused [[Robert Hannigan]], who resigned from the GCHQ on January 23, of ordering the wiretap. Hannigan reportedly resigned for personal reasons.<ref>{{cite web |last=Haddad |first=Tareq |url=http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/gchq-did-not-spy-donald-trump-security-official-confirms-1611628 |title=GCHQ did not spy on Donald Trump, security official confirms |date=March 15, 2017 |work=International Business Times |accessdate=March 18, 2017}}</ref> Fox News anchor [[Bret Baier]] later stated that "the Fox News division was never able to back up [Napolitano's] claims."<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://money.cnn.com/2017/03/17/media/fox-news-donald-trump-andrew-napolitano/index.html|title=Reporting or commentary? Napolitano claim shows Fox's blurry line|last=Stelter|first=Brian|date=March 17, 2017|website=CNNMoney|access-date=March 20, 2017}}</ref> Napolitano was reportedly temporarily taken off air by Fox due to the allegations.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/entertainment/tv/fox-pulls-napolitano-from-air-after-trump-report/2017/03/20/d87cdd92-0ddf-11e7-aa57-2ca1b05c41b8_story.html|title=Fox pulls Napolitano from air after Trump report|last=Bauder|first=David|date=March 20, 2017|work=The Washington Post|access-date=April 4, 2017|issn=0190-8286}}</ref> One of Napolitano's sources was former intelligence officer [[Larry C. Johnson]], who later told [[CNN]] that Napolitano had misrepresented the statements he made on an online discussion board. Johnson, citing two anonymous sources, claimed that the GCHQ was passing information on the Trump campaign to US intelligence through a "back-channel", but stressed that the GCHQ did not "wiretap" Trump or his associates and that alleged information sharing by the GCHQ was not done at the direction of the Obama administration.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://thehill.com/homenews/324707-ex-intelligence-official-napolitanos-british-wire-tapping-claim-didnt-get-it-right|title=Ex-intelligence official: Napolitano's British wiretapping claim 'didn't get it right'|last=Master|first=Cyra|date=March 19, 2017|work=TheHill|access-date=April 4, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://money.cnn.com/2017/03/19/media/larry-johnson-napolitano-fox-news/index.html|title=Consultant says he wasn't "knowingly" source for Napolitano report|last=Disis|first=Jill|date=March 19, 2017|website=CNNMoney|access-date=April 4, 2017}}</ref>
On March 16, Spicer repeated Napolitano's claim at a White House press briefing. The following day, GCHQ responded with a rare public statement: "Recent allegations made by media commentator Judge Andrew Napolitano about GCHQ being asked to conduct 'wiretapping' against the then president-elect are nonsense. They are utterly ridiculous and should be ignored."<ref>{{cite web |last1=Gambino |first1=Lauren |last2=Rawlinson |first2=Kevin |title=GCHQ dismisses 'utterly ridiculous' claim it helped wiretap Trump |url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2017/mar/16/gchq-denies-wiretap-claim-trump-obama |website=The Guardian |accessdate=March 17, 2017}}</ref> A British government source said the allegation was "totally untrue and quite frankly absurd".<ref name="Swinford" /> Admiral [[Michael S. Rogers]], director of the [[National Security Agency]] (NSA), said he has seen nothing to suggest that there was "any such activity" nor any request to do so.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/03/20/us/politics/takeaways-russia-intelligence-committee-hearing.html?_r=0|title=Highlights From the House Hearing on Russian Interference in the U.S. Election|last=Shane|first=Scott|date=March 20, 2017|work=The New York Times|accessdate=March 21, 2017}}</ref> Former GCHQ director [[David Omand]] told ''[[Financial Times]]'' that "The suggestion that [Barack Obama] asked GCHQ to spy on Trump is just completely barking — that would be evident to anyone who knew the system."<ref name=":5" />
The claim started a diplomatic dispute with Britain. [[Tim Farron]], the [[Liberal Democrats (UK)|Liberal Democrat]] leader in Britain, said "Trump is compromising the vital UK-US security relationship to try to cover his own embarrassment. This harms our and US security."<ref name="Swinford" /> ''The Telegraph'' said that two U.S. officials had personally apologized for the allegation.<ref name="Swinford">{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2017/03/17/us-makes-formal-apology-britain-white-house-accuses-gchq-wiretapping/|title=Donald Trump fuels diplomatic row with Britain after apology from US officials over GCHQ wiretapping claims|last=Swinford|first=Steven|date=March 18, 2017|work=The Telegraph|accessdate=March 21, 2017}}</ref> The British government also said that the U.S. government promised not to repeat these claims.<ref>{{cite web |last=Adam |first=Karla |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/worldviews/wp/2017/03/17/britains-gchq-breaks-its-silence-to-slap-down-claim-it-was-involved-in-trump-wiretap/ |title=Britain: White House says it won't repeat claims that a British agency wiretapped Trump |work=The Washington Post |date=March 17, 2017 |accessdate=March 18, 2017}}</ref><ref name=":5">{{Cite web|url=https://www.ft.com/content/ee7663bc-0a7d-11e7-97d1-5e720a26771b|title=White House reassures UK it will not repeat Trump spying claim|last=Weaver|first=|last2=Jones|date=March 17, 2017|website=Financial Times|access-date=}}</ref> The White House denied reports that it had apologized to the British government, saying Spicer was merely "pointing to public reports" without endorsing them.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Westcott |first1=Ben |last2=Merica |first2=Dan |last3=Sciutto |first3=Jim |url=http://www.cnn.com/2017/03/17/politics/gchq-trump-wiretap-denial/index.html |title=White House: No apology to British government over spying claims |date=March 17, 2017 |work=CNN |accessdate=March 18, 2017}}</ref><ref name="Swinford" />
On April 12, 2017, ''The Guardian'' reported that GCHQ (and other European intelligence agencies) had intercepted communications between members of the Trump campaign team and Russian officials, and shared the intelligence with their US counterparts. The communications were obtained through "incidental collection" as part of routine surveillance of Russian intelligence assets, not from a targeted operation against Trump or his campaign.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2017/apr/13/british-spies-first-to-spot-trump-team-links-russia|title=British spies were first to spot Trump team's links with Russia|last=Harding|first=Luke|date=April 13, 2017|work=The Guardian|access-date=May 12, 2017|last2=Kirchgaessner|first2=Stephanie|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077|last3=Hopkins|first3=Nick}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.cnn.com/2017/04/13/politics/trump-russia-british-intelligence/index.html|title=British intelligence passed Trump associates' communications with Russians on to US counterparts|author1=Jim Sciutto |author2=Pamela Brown |author3=Eric Bradner|publisher=CNN|access-date=May 12, 2017}}</ref>
Shortly after FBI James Comey publicly announced the counterintelligence investigation into Russian collusion, Robert Hannigan flew to Washington, D.C., according to The New Yorker: "Robert Hannigan, then the head of the U.K.'s intelligence service the G.C.H.Q., had recently flown to Washington and briefed the C.I.A.'s director, John Brennan, on a stream of illicit communications between Trump's team and Moscow that had been intercepted. (The content of these intercepts has not become public.)" <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2018/03/12/christopher-steele-the-man-behind-the-trump-dossier|title=Christopher Steele, the Man Behind the Trump Dossier|publisher=|accessdate=October 20, 2018}}</ref>
=== Surveillance of Trump associates ===
==== Reports ==== On January 11, 2017, ''[[The Guardian]]'' reported<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2017/jan/10/fbi-chief-given-dossier-by-john-mccain-alleging-secret-trump-russia-contacts|title=John McCain passes dossier alleging secret Trump-Russia contacts to FBI|last=Borger|first=Julian|date=January 11, 2017|work=The Guardian|access-date=March 19, 2017|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077}}</ref> that the FBI initially applied for a FISA warrant in June 2016, requesting to "monitor four members of the Trump team suspected of irregular contacts with Russian officials." This initial request was denied. A source told ''The Guardian'' that the FBI then submitted a more narrowly focused request in October, "but that has not been confirmed, and it is not clear whether any warrant led to a full investigation." ''The Guardian'' article was not cited by the [[White House Press Secretary|White House]] in connection with Trump's wiretapping claim.<ref name="HtStreetcopypasta" />
The day after ''The Guardian'' report, ''[[BBC]]'' journalist [[Paul Wood (journalist)|Paul Wood]] separately reported that, in response to an April 2016 tip from a foreign intelligence agency to the CIA about "money from the Kremlin going into the US presidential campaign", a joint task force had been established including representatives of the FBI, the [[US Department of the Treasury|Department of the Treasury]], the [[United States Department of Justice|Department of Justice]] (DOJ), the [[Central Intelligence Agency]] (CIA), the [[Office of the Director of National Intelligence]] (ODNI) and the NSA; and in June 2016 lawyers from the FBI had applied to the FISA court for "permission to intercept the electronic records from two Russian banks." The BBC alleged that the investigation was prompted in April 2016 by a "tip" from an intelligence agency of one of the [[Baltic states|Baltic States]]. According to Wood, this application was rejected, as was a more narrowly focused request in July, and the order was finally granted by a different FISA judge on October 15, three weeks before the presidential election. According to the article, the warrant did not name Trump or his associates.<ref name="BBC">{{cite web|title=Trump 'compromising' claims: How and why did we get here?|author=Paul Wood|work=BBC|date=January 12, 2017|accessdate=March 7, 2017|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-38589427}}</ref>
On January 18, [[The McClatchy Company|''McClatchy'']] separately<ref name="HtStreetcopypasta" /> reported<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.mcclatchydc.com/news/politics-government/article127231799.html|title=FBI, 5 other agencies probe possible covert Kremlin aid to Trump|work=mcclatchydc|access-date=March 22, 2017|language=en}}</ref> that "the FBI had obtained a warrant on Oct. 15 from the highly secretive Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court allowing investigators access to bank records and other documents about potential payments and money transfers related to Russia." The ''McClatchy'' article was not cited by the [[White House Press Secretary|White House]] in connection with Trump's wiretapping claim.<ref name="HtStreetcopypasta" />
In April 2017, ''The Washington Post'' initially reported that the FBI secured a FISA warrant to monitor Trump campaign associate [[Carter Page]] in the summer of 2016 — later corrected to October 2016, one month after Page had left the Trump campaign. The warrant was reportedly based on the possibility that Page was acting as an agent of a foreign government, i.e., Russia.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Nakashima |first1=Ellen |last2=Barrett |first2=Devlin |last3=Entous |first3=Adam |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/fbi-obtained-fisa-warrant-to-monitor-former-trump-adviser-carter-page/2017/04/11/620192ea-1e0e-11e7-ad74-3a742a6e93a7_story.html |title=FBI obtained FISA warrant to monitor Trump adviser Carter Page |date=April 11, 2017 |work=The Washington Post |accessdate=September 19, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last1=Green |first1=Miranda |url=http://www.cnn.com/2017/04/12/politics/fbi-carter-page-russia/index.html |title=FBI monitored former Trump campaign adviser Carter Page on Russia |publisher=[[CNN]] |date=April 12, 2017 |accessdate=September 19, 2017}}</ref>
On September 18, 2017, [[CNN]] reported that the FBI wiretapped [[Paul Manafort]], Trump's former campaign chairman, from as early as 2014 through an unspecified time before the 2016 election, and also after the election through early 2017, pursuant to two separate FISA court orders. It has not been confirmed whether Trump's conversations with Manafort were intercepted as part of this surveillance. CNN acknowledged that prior to this disclosure, "speculation has run rampant about whether Manafort or others associated with Trump were under surveillance." The CNN report noted that it was unclear if Manafort was under FBI surveillance while he resided in Trump Tower.<ref name="Manafort wiretap">{{cite web |last1=Perez |first1=Evan |last2=Prokupecz |first2=Shimon |last3=Brown |first3=Pamela |url=http://www.cnn.com/2017/09/18/politics/paul-manafort-government-wiretapped-fisa-russians/index.html |title=Exclusive: US government wiretapped former Trump campaign chairman |publisher=[[CNN]] |date=September 18, 2017 |accessdate=September 19, 2017}}</ref>
==== Analysis ==== In its March 5 analysis of the reporting that preceded Trump's allegations, ''[[The Washington Post]]'' stated that "the articles all suggest that the FISA requests—if they happened—were done by the intelligence agencies and the FBI," and not by the Obama administration. According to ''The Post'', Mensch's article was the only one to have alleged any surveillance of Trump Tower. No major news organizations have been able to confirm Mensch's account,<ref name=":4" /> despite prolonged efforts by ''The New York Times'' and ''The Washington Post''. This absence of verification, combined with Mensch's reliance on "vague"<ref name=":3">{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/03/05/us/politics/trump-phone-tapping-surveillance-issues.html|title=What Can Be Gleaned From Trump's Allegations of Wiretapping|last=Savage|first=Charlie|date=March 5, 2017|work=The New York Times|access-date=April 4, 2017|issn=0362-4331}}</ref> and anonymous sourcing to individuals "with links to the counter-intelligence community," lead ''The Times'' and ''The Post'' to urge skepticism about the veracity of her account.<ref name=":3" /><ref name="HtStreetcopypasta" />
Some Trump supporters cited the Manafort wiretap report as vindicating Trump's March 2017 tweets.<ref name="Fox Vindicated?">{{cite news|url=http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2017/09/19/trump-vindicated-manafort-wiretapping-report-lends-credence-to-claim.html|title=Trump vindicated? Manafort wiretapping report lends credence to claim|date=September 19, 2017|publisher=Fox News|accessdate=September 20, 2017}}</ref> However, David A. Graham of ''[[The Atlantic]]'' responded: "This is not true—Trump claimed he had been the subject of Obama-ordered, politically motivated surveillance, for which there remains no evidence." While acknowledging that "it does make for a more complicated picture than previously known," Graham argued "there are reasons to doubt" that Trump was even aware of the Manafort wiretap at the time he made his unsupported allegations against Obama. Graham concluded: "Insofar as there are parallels between what Pollak, Levin, and Napolitano said and the new story, it looks like luck."<ref name="Graham Not Vindicated">{{cite web|last=Graham|first=David A.|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2017/09/does-the-latest-manafort-news-vindicate-trumps-wiretap-claim/540321/|title=Is Trump's 'Wiretap' Claim Vindicated?|work=[[The Atlantic]]|date=September 19, 2017|accessdate=September 20, 2017}}</ref> Aaron Blake of ''The Washington Post'' noted that, according to CNN, lawyers for both Trump and Manafort convinced the two men to discontinue their phone conversations some time after Trump took office: "If Trump's lawyers somehow knew about and fought back against the Manafort wiretap, it stands to reason that Trump himself might have been aware of it. ... While we don't know the exact timing of all of this, perhaps this is what Trump was referring to and he, as he is wont to do, exaggerated it."<ref name="Blake Wash Post">{{cite web|last=Blake|first=Aaron|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-fix/wp/2017/09/19/cnn-says-the-government-wiretapped-manafort-does-that-vindicate-trumps-obama-wiretapped-me-claims/|title=CNN says Manafort was wiretapped. Does that vindicate Trump's Obama-spied-on-me claims?|work=[[The Washington Post]]|date=September 19, 2017|accessdate=September 25, 2017}}</ref>
== Reactions == There has been criticism of Trump's claim as simply being a "[[Dead cat strategy|dead cat]]", a false allegation against Obama intended to direct media and public interest away from Trump and his team's alleged connections with Russia.<ref name="bbcnews1">{{cite news| url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-39221378|title=Trump and the media – Is it war or love?|publisher=[[BBC]]|date=March 10, 2017|accessdate=March 11, 2017}}</ref>
=== From politicians === Most Republicans in Congress distanced themselves from the claim and refused to comment on it, although members of both the [[United States Senate|Senate]] and [[United States House of Representatives|House of Representatives]] vowed to investigate the matter.<ref name="The Guardian no evidence">{{Cite news|title=Top Republicans refuse to back up Trump's unproven wiretapping claim |author=Sabrina Siddiqui, David Smith |date=March 8, 2017 |newspaper=The Guardian |url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2017/mar/07/trump-wiretap-obama-republicans-us-intelligence }}</ref>
Obama spokesman Kevin Lewis repudiated the claim in a statement later that day saying: "A cardinal rule of the Obama administration was that no White House official ever interfered with any independent investigation led by the Department of Justice."<ref name="WaPost no evidence" /> ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'' described Obama as "livid" when he heard about the allegations personally,<ref name="Business Insider">{{cite news|author=Brian Logan|title=Obama is reportedly 'furious' over Trump's unsubstantiated wiretapping allegations|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/obama-responds-trump-wiretapping-claim-2017-3|work=Business Insider|date=March 8, 2017}}</ref> though other sources said he "rolled his eyes" and remained more concerned about Trump's conservative and nationalist agenda.<ref name="The Hill">{{cite news|author=Rebecca Savransky|title=Obama 'rolled his eyes' at Trump's wiretap accusation|url=http://thehill.com/blogs/blog-briefing-room/news/322945-obama-rolled-his-eyes-at-trumps-wiretap-accusation|work=The Hill|date=March 8, 2017}}</ref> When the Obama administration's former press secretary [[Josh Earnest]] was asked by [[ABC News]]'s [[Martha Raddatz]] if he could deny that the Obama Justice Department had sought and obtained a FISA court-ordered wiretap of the Trump campaign, he responded, "I don't know ... The president was not giving marching orders to the FBI about how to conduct their investigations."<ref name="Raddatz Earnest 1">{{cite web |url=http://abcnews.go.com/Politics/week-transcript-17-sarah-huckabee-sanders-josh-earnest/story?id=45911284 |title='This Week' Transcript 3-5-17: Sarah Huckabee Sanders, Josh Earnest, and Sen. Al Franken |publisher=[[ABC News]] |date=March 5, 2017 |accessdate=September 24, 2017}}</ref><ref name="Raddatz Earnest 2">{{cite web |last=Dukakis |first=Ali |url=http://abcnews.go.com/Politics/obama-spokesman-trump-working-hard-distract-growing-scandal/story?id=45911024 |title=Former Obama spokesman: Trump 'working very hard' to distract from 'growing scandal'|publisher=[[ABC News]] |date=March 5, 2017 |accessdate=September 24, 2017}}</ref>
On March 23, [[Devin Nunes]] stated that communications to and from [[Presidential transition of Donald Trump|Trump's presidential transition team]] may have been intercepted as part of incidental collection.<ref name="Rosenberg Goldman Huetteman 2017">{{cite web | last=Rosenberg | first=Matthew | last2=Goldman | first2=Adam | last3=Huetteman | first3=Emmarie | title=Monitoring May Have 'Incidentally' Picked Up Trump Aides, House Member Says | website=The New York Times | date=March 20, 2017 | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/03/22/us/politics/devin-nunes-wiretapping-trump.html | access-date=December 29, 2017}}</ref> In response, officials in the Obama administration refuted any claims that it had been monitoring the Trump team. Nunes said the surveillance was unrelated to the Russia investigation and "suggested the contents may have been inappropriately disseminated in intelligence reports ... for political reasons."<ref name=":2">{{cite web|url=http://bigstory.ap.org/8f45d6141e4e4cce86024af85841a9f7|title=Spying claim by Intel chair renews fight over Russia probe|publisher=Associated Press|date=March 22, 2017|access-date=March 23, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170324020019/http://bigstory.ap.org/8f45d6141e4e4cce86024af85841a9f7|archive-date=March 24, 2017|deadurl=no}} * See also {{cite tweet|user=AP|number=844601141908455425|title=GOP lawmaker says President Trump's communications may have been 'monitored' during transition period. |date=March 22, 2017|access-date=March 23, 2017}}</ref> Later the same day, Nunes said that he did not know "for sure" whether intelligence committees had actually monitored the Trump team's communications.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.latimes.com/nation/la-na-pol-russia-investigation-20170324-story.html|title=House Intelligence chair partially backs off claim about surveillance of Trump transition team|last=Cloud|first=David S.|date=March 23, 2017|work=Los Angeles Times|access-date=March 24, 2017|last2=Willman|first2=David|language=en-US|issn=0458-3035}}</ref> In September, former [[National Security Advisor (United States)|National Security Advisor]] [[Susan Rice]] stated that a December 2016 Trump Tower meeting between Trump transition officials and [[Mohammed bin Zayed Al Nahyan]] of the [[United Arab Emirates]] (UAE) raised suspicions because the UAE allegedly failed to give the Obama administration advance notice of Zayed's visit to the U.S., as is customary. Therefore, to better understand the intent of the meeting, she "requested the names of the Americans mentioned in the classified report be revealed internally" (or "[[Masking and unmasking by intelligence agencies|unmasked]]"). According to [[CNN]]'s Manu Ragu, while Nunes implied that such "unmasking" may have been improper—an allegation that the Trump administration used to deflect from Trump's original wiretap claim—Rice's "explanation appears to have satisfied some influential Republicans on the committee, undercutting both Nunes and Trump." Republican Representative [[Mike Conaway]] affirmed: "She was a good witness, answered all our questions. I'm not aware of any reason to bring her back."<ref>{{cite web|last=Ragu|first=Manu|url=http://www.cnn.com/2017/09/13/politics/susan-rice-house-investigators-unmasked-trump-officials/index.html|title=Exclusive: Rice told House investigators why she unmasked senior Trump officials|publisher=[[CNN]]|date=September 18, 2017|accessdate=September 19, 2017}}</ref>
Republican Senator [[Rand Paul]] pointed out that a backdoor intercept of Trump's communications was possible.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.usnews.com/news/articles/2017-03-13/authorities-intercepted-1-227-obama-calls-rand-paul-says-misreading-report-to-explain-trump|work=U.S. News & World Report|first=Steven|title=Authorities Intercepted 1,227 Obama Calls, Rand Paul Says, Misreading Report to Explain Trump|last=Nelson}}</ref> Elizabeth Goitein, a surveillance law expert at [[New York University School of Law|New York University]], pointed out that backdoor searches of incidental records collected on Americans overseas were allowed by U.S. law.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.usnews.com/news/articles/2017-03-07/will-trumps-wiretap-claim-prove-true|title=Will Trump's Wiretap Claim Prove True?|work=U.S. News & World Report|date=March 7, 2017|first=Steven|last=Nelson}}</ref> Republican Representative [[Frank LoBiondo]], a senior member on the House Intelligence Committee, speculated on March 20, after Comey's testimony to the Committee, that it was possible there was incidental collection that occurred due to targeting Russian communications, but expressed doubt that there was any evidence that there was such a wiretap.<ref>{{cite interview|url=https://www.npr.org/2017/03/20/520788195/house-committee-hosts-1st-public-hearing-into-russia-election-interference|date=March 20, 2017|title=House Committee Hosts Public Hearing Into Russia Election Interference|interviewer=David Greene|first=David|last=LoBiondo|quote= There is no evidence demonstrating that there was a wiretap. What – now, was there something incidental that there was some listening on the Russians that somehow touched on that? …it's possible… I don't think there's any evidence anything went on.|publisher=NPR}}</ref> Incidental collection—also called backdoor collection by politicians such as Democratic Senator [[Ron Wyden]]<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/aug/09/nsa-loophole-warrantless-searches-email-calls|title=NSA loophole allows warrantless search for US citizens' emails and phone calls|date=August 9, 2013|first1=James |last1=Ball|first2=Spencer |last2=Ackerman|publisher=''The Guardian''}}</ref>—has been publicly acknowledged by the intelligence community for years.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/04/02/us/politics/letter-puts-focus-on-us-searches-for-americans-emails-and-calls.html|date=April 1, 2014|title=Letter Tells of U.S. Searches for Emails and Calls|first=Charlie|last=Savage|newspaper=The New York Times}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Letter to Senators Wyden|work=The New York Times|via=Charlie Savage|date=March 28, 2017|url=https://www.documentcloud.org/documents/1100298-unclassified-702-response.html|publisher=Director of National Intelligence|first=James|last=Clapper}}</ref>
=== From U.S. government agencies === On March 4, FBI director [[James Comey]] asked the Justice Department to issue a statement refuting Trump's claims.<ref name="Comey refute" /> Speaking to NBC's ''Meet the Press'', former Director of National Intelligence [[James Clapper]] said "For the part of the national security apparatus that I oversaw as DNI there was no such wiretap activity mounted against the President-elect at the time, or as a candidate, or against his campaign."<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.cnn.com/2017/03/05/politics/clapper-trump-wiretap/index.html|title=Clapper: 'No such wiretap activity mounted' on Trump|last=Diamond|first=Jeremy|date=March 5, 2017|publisher=CNN|access-date=March 21, 2017}}</ref>
At a [[House Intelligence Committee]] open hearing on March 20, 2017, Comey stated that neither the FBI nor the Justice Department possessed any information to support Trump's wiretapping allegations.<ref name="nyt_comey">{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/03/20/us/politics/intelligence-committee-russia-donald-trump.html|title=Comey Confirms F.B.I. Investigation of Russian Election Interference, Links to Trump Campaign|date=March 20, 2017|work=[[The New York Times]] |last2=Huetteman |first2=Emmarie |last3=Schmidt |first3=Michael |last1=Rosenberg |first1=Matthew |accessdate=March 20, 2017}}</ref>
On September 1, 2017, a DOJ court filing stated that "both the FBI and NSD <nowiki>[</nowiki>[[United States Department of Justice National Security Division]]<nowiki>]</nowiki> confirm that they have no records related to wiretaps as described by the March 4, 2017 tweets." Furthermore, it said that the Department of Justice and the FBI "[[Glomar response|do not confirm or deny the existence]]" of any other records that are responsive to American Oversight's [[Freedom of Information Act (United States)|FOIA]] request, which was broader than the alleged wiretaps of Trump Tower.<ref name="Justice Department">{{Cite web |last=Walsh |first=Deirdre |url=http://www.cnn.com/2017/09/02/politics/justice-department-trump-tower-wiretap/index.html |title=Justice Department: No evidence Trump Tower was wiretapped |date=September 2, 2017 |publisher=CNN |access-date=September 12, 2017}}</ref>

revision.comment: /* History */I added a documentary filmmaker who made educational art films in Chicago, IL while working for The Art Institute of Chicago in museum education. These short films were made mostly between 1973 and 1998. She had a producer credit but stood at the helm of each film.
